RegisterGroup.name: CHAN0_CIPHER_DOUT
RegisterGroup.description:
CHAN0_CIPHER_DOUT is the CIPHER output register for channel 0 (for single-blockencryption/decryption).The data read from this register is the results of a single-block operation. The results of theAES algorithm are different from those of the DES or 3DES algorithm. The details are asfollows:
  • For the AES algorithm- If the 1-CFB mode is selected, the least significant bit (LSB) is valid, that is,CIPHER_DOUT bit[0] is valid.- If the 8-CFB mode is selected, lower eight bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_DOUTbit[7:0] is valid.- If the 128-CFB mode is selected, 128 bits are valid.- In other modes, 128 bits are valid.
  • For the DES or 3DES algorithm- If the 1-CFB or 1-OFB mode is selected, the LSB is valid, that is, CIPHER_DOUTbit[0] is valid.- If the 8-CFB or 8-OFB mode is selected, lower eight bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_DOUT bit[7:0] is valid.- If the 64-CFB or 64-OFB mode is selected, lower 64 bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_DOUT bit[63:0] is valid.- In other modes, lower 64 bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_DOUT bit[63:0] is valid.

Member.name: chan0_cipher_dout
Member.description:
128-bit block output of the CIPHER module. Each address maps to a 32-bit data segment.
CIPHER_DOUT[31:0]: address 0x0000
CIPHER_DOUT[63:32]: address 0x0004
CIPHER_DOUT[95:64]: address 0x0008
CIPHER_DOUT[127:96]: address 0x000C

RegisterGroup.name: CHAN0_CIPHER_IVOUT
RegisterGroup.description:
CHAN0_CIPHER_IVOUT is an operation complete IV output register of the CIPHERmodule.Note the following points when reading this register:
  • This register can be ignored in ECB or CTR mode.
  • If a single-block operation is performed, the data of this register is the vector output ofthe block. The data can be used as the vector input in the next block operation for thesame data packet.- If the AES algorithm is selected, 128 bits are valid.- If the DES or 3DES algorithm is selected (CIPHER_CTRL[cipher_mode] = 0b00,0b01, or 0b11), lower 64 bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_IVOUT bit[63:0] is valid.
  • If a multi-block operation is performed, the data read from this register is the outputvector of the last block operation.- If the AES algorithm is selected, 128 bits are valid.- If the DES or 3DES algorithm is selected, lower 64 bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_IVOUT bit[63:0] is valid.

Member.name: chan0_cipher_ivout
Member.description:
Vector output after the operation of the CIPHER module is complete. It can be ignored in ECB or CTR mode. Each address maps to a 32-bit data segment.
CIPHER_DOUT[31:0]: address 0x0010
CIPHER_IVOUT[63:32]: address 0x0014
CIPHER_IVOUT[95:64]: address 0x0018
CIPHER_IVOUT[127:96]: address 0x001C

RegisterGroup.name: CHAN_CIPHER_IVOUT
RegisterGroup.description: CHAN_CIPHER_IVOUT is the IV output register for channels 1–7.

Member.name: chan_cipher_ivout
Member.description:
0x0020–0x002C: channel 1
0x0030–0x003C: channel 2
0x0040–0x004C: channel 3
0x0050–0x005C: channel 4
0x0060–0x006C: channel 5
0x0070–0x007C: channel 6
0x0080–0x008C: channel 7

RegisterGroup.name: CIPHER_KEY
RegisterGroup.description:
CIPHER_KEY is a CPU configuration key register of the CIPHER module. The key is theconfigured value of the CPU, and the CPU can be read or written.Note the following points when configuring this register:
  • If the DES algorithm is selected, lower 64 bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_KEY[63:0] isvalid.
  • For the 3DES algorit
    • T)If a 3-key operation is performed (CIPHER_CTRL[key_length] = 0b00, 0b01, or 0b10),low 192 bits are valid.where- CIPHER_KEY bit[63:0] indicates key 1.- CIPHER_KEY bit[127:64] indicates key 2.- CIPHER_KEY bit[191:128] indicates key 3.If a 2-key operation is selected (CIPHER_CTRL[key_length] = 0b11), lower 128 bits arevalid.where- CIPHER_KEY bit[63:0] indicates key 1.- CIPHER_KEY bit[127:64] indicates key 2.
  • For the AES algorithm- If a 128-bit key operation is performed, lower 128 bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_KEY bit[127:0] is valid.- If a 192-bit key operation is performed, lower 192 bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_KEY bit[191:0] is valid.- If a 256-bit key operation is performed, 256 bits are valid.The CIPHER module allows you to configure eight keys. Each channel can use one key, andmultiple channels can share one key.

Member.name: cipher_key
Member.description:
Key input of the CIPHER module. Each address maps to a 32-bit data segment.
CIPHER_KEY[31:0]: address 0x0090
CIPHER_KEY[63:32]: address 0x0094
CIPHER_KEY[95:64]: address 0x0098
CIPHER_KEY[127:96]: address 0x009C
CIPHER_KEY[159: 128]: address 0x00A0
CIPHER_KEY[191:160]: address 0x00A4
CIPHER_KEY[223:192]: address 0x00A8
CIPHER_KEY[255:224]: address 0x00AC
0x0090–0x00AC: host_key0
0x00B0–0x00CC: host_key1
0x00D0–0x00EC: host_key2
0x00F0–0x010C: host_key3
0x0110–0x012C: host_key4
0x0130–0x014C: host_key5
0x0150–0x016C: host_key6
0x0170–0x018C: host_key7

RegisterGroup.name: CHAN0_CIPHER_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description:
CHAN0_CIPHER_CTRL is the encryption/decryption control register for channel 0. Channel0 is a single-block encryption/decryption channel.Note the following points when configuring this register:
  • Configure this register before configuring others registers of the CIPHER module.
  • In the modes except the CFB mode of the AES algorithm, the CIPHER_CTRL[width]cannot be set to 01 or 10.
  • In the modes except the CFB and OFB modes of the DES and 3DES algorithms,CIPHER_CTRL[width] cannot be set to 01 or 10.

Member.name: key_adder
Member.description:
ID of the key used by the current channel.
000: host_key0
001: host_key1
010: host_key2
011: host_key3
100: host_key4
101: host_key5
110: host_key6
111: host_key7

Member.name: key_sel
Member.description:
Key select.
0: keys configured by the CPU
1: keys generated by the key management module

Member.name: key_length
Member.description:
Key length select.
For the AES algorithm:
00: 128 bits
01: 192bits
10: 256 bits
11: 128 bits
For the DES algorithm:
00: 3 keys
01: 3 keys
10: 3 keys
11: 2 keys

Member.name: ivin_sel
Member.description:
Input select of CIPHER_IVIN.
0: do not configure CIPHER_IVIN
1: configure CIPHER_IVIN

Member.name: width
Member.description:
Bit width control.
For the DES or 3DES algorithm:
00: 64 bits
01: 8 bits
10: 1 bit
11: 64 bits
For the AES algorithm:
00: 128 bits
01: 8 bits
10: 1 bit
11: 128 bits

Member.name: alg_sel
Member.description:
Algorithm select.
00: DES algorithm
01: 3DES algorithm
10: AES algorithm
11: DES algorithm

Member.name: mode
Member.description:
Operating mode select.
For the AES algorithm:
000: ECB mode
001: CBC mode
010: CFB mode
011: OFB mode
100: CTR mode
Other values: ECB mode
For the DES algorithm:
000: ECB mode
001: CBC mode
010: CFB mode
011: OFB mode
Other values: ECB mode

Member.name: decrypt
Member.description:
Encryption/decryption select.
0: encryption
1: decryption

RegisterGroup.name: CHAN0_CIPHER_IVIN
RegisterGroup.description:
CHAN0_CIPHER_IVIN is the CIPHER VI block input register for channel 0.Assume that channel 0 is selected for the single-block encryption/decryption and the selectedmode is not ECB mode (CIPHER_CTRL[mode] = 0b001, 0b010, 0b011, or 0b100).
  • If you do not want to configure the input vector (CIPHER_CTRL[ivin_sel] = 0b0),CIPHER_IVIN can be ignored.
  • If you want to configure the input vector (CIPHER_CTRL[ivin_sel] = 0b1),CIPHER_IVIN needs to be configured. If the AES algorithm is selected(CIPHER_CTRL [alg_sel] = 0b10), CIPHER_IVIN bit[127:0] is valid. If the DES or3DES algorithm is selected (CIPHER_CTRL[alg_sel] = 0b00, 0b01, or 0b11), lower 64bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_IVIN bit[63:0] is valid.

Member.name: chan0_cipher_ivin
Member.description:
128-bit IV of the CIPHER module for channel 0 or the data input from the counter. Each address maps to a 32-bit data segment.
CIPHER_IVIN[31:0]: address 0x1004
CIPHER_IVIN[63:32]: address 0x1008
CIPHER_IVIN[95:64]: address 0x100C
CIPHER_IVIN[127:96]: address 0x1010

RegisterGroup.name: CHAN0_CIPHER_DIN
RegisterGroup.description:
CHAN0_CIPHER_DIN is a 128-bit block input register of the CIPHER module.Note the following points when configuring this register:If channel 0 is selected for the single-block operation, this register needs to be configured.
  • Assume that the AES algorithm (CIPHER_CTRL[alg_sel] = 0b10) is selected.- If the 1-CFB mode is selected, the LSB is valid, that is, CIPHER_DIN bit[0] is valid.- If the 8-CFB mode is selected, lower eight bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_DINbit[7:0] is valid.- If the 128-CFB mode is selected, 128 bits are valid.- In other modes, 128 bits are valid.
  • Assume that the DES or the 3DES algorithm (CIPHER_CTRL[alg_sel] = 0b00, 0b01, or0b11) is selected.- If the 1-CFB or 1-OFB mode is selected, the LSB is valid, that is, CIPHER_DINbit[0] is valid.- If the 8-CFB or 8-OFB mode is selected, lower eight bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_DIN bit[7:0] is valid.- If the 64-CFB or 64-OFB mode is selected, lower 64 bits are valid, that is,CIPHER_DIN bit[63:0] is valid.- In other modes, lower 64 bits are valid, that is, CIPHER_DIN bit[63:0] is valid.

Member.name: chan0_cipher_din
Member.description:
128-bit block input of the CIPHER module for channel 0. Each address maps to a 32-bit data segment.
CIPHER_DIN[31:0]: address 0x1014
CIPHER_DIN[63:32]: address 0x1018
CIPHER_DIN[95:64]: address 0x101c
CIPHER_DIN[127:96]: address 0x1020

RegisterGroup.name: CHANN_IBUF_NUM
RegisterGroup.description: CHANn_IBUF_NUM is the input queue total depth register for channel n (n = 1–7). Thisregister can be used to configure the count of linked list headers.

Member.name: ibuf_num
Member.description: Input queue depth, that is, count of linked list headers configured for each channel.

RegisterGroup.name: CHANN_IBUF_CNT
RegisterGroup.description: CHANn_IBUF_CNT is the pending data buffer count register for channel n in the input queue.When this register is written by using software, the logic adds the original value of the registerand the written value. After the logic processes a buffer, the value of this register is decreasedby 1.

Member.name: ibuf_cnt
Member.description: Count of buffers to be processed in the input queue.

RegisterGroup.name: CHANN_IEMPTY_CNT
RegisterGroup.description: CHANn_IEMPTY_CNT is the processed buffer count register for channel n in the inputqueue. When this register is written by software, the logic subtracts the written value from theoriginal value of this register. After the logic processes a buffer, the value of this register isincreased by 1.

Member.name: iempty_cnt
Member.description: Count of processed buffers in the input queue.

RegisterGroup.name: CHANN_INT_ICNTCFG
RegisterGroup.description: CHANn_INT_ICNTCFG is the input queue multi-packet interrupt threshold register forchannel n. When the count of buffers in the input queue processed by the logic is above thethreshold, an input queue interrupt is reported.

Member.name: int_icnt_cfg
Member.description: Input queue multi-packet interrupt threshold.

RegisterGroup.name: CHANN_CIPHER_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description:
CHANn_CIPHER_CTRL is the encryption/decryption control register for channel n.Note the following points when configuring this register:
  • You must configure this register before performing encryption or decryption using thechannel.
  • In the modes other than the CFB mode of the AES algorithm, CIPHER_CTRL[width]cannot be set to 01 or 10.
  • In the modes other than the CFB and OFB modes of the DES or 3DES algorithm,CIPHER_CTRL[width] cannot be set to 01 or 10.

RegisterGroup.name: CHANN_IAGE_TIMER
RegisterGroup.description: CHANn_IAGE_TIMER is the input queue interrupt aging time configuration register forchannel n. If an overflow occurs in the aging time counter and the count of processed buffersin the input queue is greater than 0, an input queue processing complete interrupt is reported.

After the logic processes a buffer, the value of this register isdecreased by 1.

Status signal of channel 0.

Member.description:
Encryption/decryption start signal of channel 0.

1: The value 1 must be written to this signal when channel 0 is enabled for encryption and decryption.

Member.name: adac_srst_req
Member.description:
Audio Codec soft reset request.
0: deassert reset
1: reset

Member.name: sio_fsclk_div
Member.description:
Division relationship between the bit clock BCLK and sampling clock FS.
000: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 16.
001: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 32.
010: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 48.
011: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 64.
100: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 128.
101: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 256.
Other values: The FS is generated by dividing the BCLK by 8.

Member.name: sio_bclk_div
Member.description:
Division relationship between the main clock MCLK and bit clock BCLK.
0000: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 1.
0001: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 3.
0010: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 2.
0011: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 4.
0100: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 6.
0101: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 8.
0110: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 12.
0111: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 16.
1000: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 24.
1001: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 32.
1010: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 48.
1011: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 64.
Other values: The BCLK is generated by dividing the MCLK by 8.

Member.name: sio_fs_rxtx_sel
Member.description:
Multiplexing relationship between the SIO TX FS and RX FS.
0: The RX FS is independent of the TX FS.
1: The TX FS multiplexes with the RX FS.

Member.name: sio_bclk_rxtx_sel
Member.description:
Multiplexing relationship between the SIO TX BCLK and RX BCLK.
0: The RX BCLK is independent of the TX BCLK.
1: The TX BCLK multiplexes with the RX BCLK.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_STAT is an interrupt status register. It shows the status of the masked interrupts.If certain bits of DMAC_INT_TC_STAT and DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT are masked at thesame time, the corresponding bit of DMAC_INT_STAT1 is also masked. Each bit ofDMAC_INT_STAT maps to one DMAC channel. When a bit is 1, an interrupt request isgenerated in the corresponding channel and the interrupt request may be an error interrupt or aterminal count interrupt.

Member.name: int_stat
Member.description:
Statuses of the masked interrupts of each DMA channel. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated. The interrupt request may be an error interrupt or a terminal count interrupt.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_TC_STAT is an terminal count interrupt status register. It shows the status of themasked terminal count interrupts. The corresponding mask bit is DMAC_Cn_CONFIG[itc],where n is the channel number ranging from 0 to 3. This register must work withOffset Address

Member.name: int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Statuses of the masked terminal count interrupts. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No terminal count interrupt is generated.
1: A terminal count interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_TC_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_TC_CLR is a terminal count interrupt clear register. It is used to clear terminalcount interrupts.

Member.name: int_tc_clr
Member.description:
Terminal count interrupt clear. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: do not clear
1: clear

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_ERR_STAT is an error interrupt status register. It shows the status of themasked error interrupts. The corresponding mask bit is DMAC_Cn_CONFIG[ie]. The registermust work with DMAC_INT_STAT.

Member.name: int_err_stat
Member.description:
Statuses of masked error interrupts. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_INT_ERR_CLR
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_INT_ERR_CLR is an error interrupt clear register. It is used to clear error interrupts.

Member.name: int_err_clr
Member.description:
Error interrupt clear. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: do not clear
1: clear

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_RAW_INT_TC_STATUS is a raw terminal count interrupt status register. It showsthe status of the raw terminal count interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_tc_stat
Member.description:
Statuses of the raw terminal count interrupt of each channel. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No terminal count interrupt is generated.
1: A terminal count interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_RAW_INT_ERR_STATUS is a raw error interrupt status register. It shows the statusof the raw error interrupt of each channel.

Member.name: raw_int_err_stat
Member.description:
Statuses of the raw error interrupt of each channel. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: No error interrupt is generated.
1: An error interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS is a DMAC channel enable status register. It shows the enabledchannels.For example, if a bit of DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS is 1, the corresponding channel is enabled.The enable bit of DMAC_Cn_CONFIG of each channel determines whether thecorresponding channel is enabled. When the DMA transfer over a channel is complete, the bitof DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS corresponding to the channel is cleared.

Member.name: enabled_channels
Member.description:
Channel enable. Bit[3:0] map to channels 3–0.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_BREQ
RegisterGroup.description:
DMAC_SOFT_BREQ is a DMA burst request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA burst request using software.
  • When this register is read, the device that is requesting the DMA burst transfer can be queried.This register and any peripheral each can generate a DAM request.
NOTE
It is not recommended to generate a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the sametime.

Member.name: soft_breq
Member.description:
Controls whether to generate a DMA burst transfer request. For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-24.
When this register is written:
0: no effect
1: A DMA burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] does not transmit a DMA burst request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACBREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA burst transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_SREQ
RegisterGroup.description:
DMAC_SOFT_SREQ is a DMA single request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA single transfer request using software.
  • When this register is read, the device that is requesting the DMA single transfer can bequeried. This register and any of the 16 DMA request input signals of the DMAC each cangenerate a DMA request.
NOTE
It is not recommended to generate a software DMA request and a hardware DMA request at the sametime.

Member.name: soft_sreq
Member.description:
Controls whether to generate a DMA burst transfer request. For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-24.
When this register is written:
0: no effect
1: A DMA single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.
When this register is read:
0: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACSREQ[15:0] does not transmit a DMA single request.
1: The peripheral corresponding to the request signal DMACSREQ[15:0] is requesting a DMA single transfer.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LBREQ
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SOFT_LBREQ is a DMA last burst request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA last burst transfer request using software.

Member.name: soft_lbreq
Member.description:
Last burst request issued by the software.
0: no effect
1: A DMA last burst transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SOFT_LSREQ
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SOFT_LSREQ is a DMA last single request register for software. It is used to controlwhether to generate a DMA last single transfer request.

Member.name: soft_lsreq
Member.description:
Last single transfer request issued by the software.
0: no effect
1: A DMA last single transfer request is generated. When the transfer is complete, the corresponding bit is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description:
DMAC_CONFIG is a DMAC configuration register. It is used to configure DMACoperations. You can change the endian modes of the two master interfaces of the DMAC bywriting to m1 (bit[1]) and m2 (bit[2]) of this register. After reset, the modes of the two masterinterfaces are set to little endian.NOTE
Both Masters work in little endian mode.

Member.name: m2
Member.description:
Endian mode of Master 2.
0: little endian mode
1: big endian mode

Member.name: m1
Member.description:
Endian mode of Master 1.
0: little endian mode
1: big endian mode

Member.name: e
Member.description:
DMAC enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_SYNC
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_SYNC is a DMAC synchronization register. It is used to enable or disable thesynchronization logic provided for DMA request signals.

Member.name: dmac_sync
Member.description:
Controls whether to synchronize the request signals. For details about the request corresponding to each bit, see Table 3-24.
0: enable the synchronization logic provided for the DMA request signals of the corresponding peripheral.
1: disable the synchronization logic provided for the DMA request signals of the corresponding peripheral.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CN_SRC_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
DMAC_Cn_SRC_ADDR is a DMAC source address register. It shows the source addresses(sorted by byte) of the data to be transferred.The offset address of the register is 0x100+n x 0x20. The value of n ranges from 0 to 3. Thevalues 0–3 map to DMA channels 0–3.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed using software.After the channel is enabled, the register is updated in the following cases:
  • The source address is incremented.
  • A complete data block is transferred and then loaded from LLI nodes.When a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This isbecause that after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer.Therefore, the register is read after the channel stops data transfer. At this time, the read valueis the last source address read by the DMAC.The source and destination addresses must be aligned with the transfer widths of the sourceand destination devices.

Member.name: src_addr
Member.description: DMA source address.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CN_DEST_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
DMAC_Cn_DEST_ADDR is a destination address register. Its offset address is 0x104 + n x0x20. The value of n ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 map to DMA channels 0–3.This register contains the destination address (sorted by byte) of the data to be transferred.Before a channel is enabled, its corresponding register must be programmed using software.After the channel is enabled, the register is updated in the following cases:
  • Destination address increment.
  • A complete data block is transferred and then loaded from LLI nodes.When a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This isbecause that after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer.Therefore, the register is read after the channel stops data transfer. At this time, the read valueis the last destination address written by the DMAC.

Member.name: dest_addr
Member.description: DMA destination address.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CNLLI
RegisterGroup.description:
DMAC_CnLLI is a DMAC LLI register. Its offset address is 0x108 + n x 0x20. The value ofn ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 map to DMA channels 0–3.The data structure of a DMAC LLI node is as follows:
  • Channel register DMAC_Cn_SRC_ADDR, for setting the start address of the sourcedeviceChannel register DMAC_Cn_DEST_ADDR, for setting the start address of thedestination deviceChannel register DMAC_CnLLI, for setting the address of the next nodeChannel register DMAC_Cn_CONTROL, for setting the master, data width, burst size,address increment, and transfer size of the source device and destination deviceStructure of DMAC LLIs
CAUTIONThe value of the LLI field must be less than or equal to 0xFFFF_FFF0. Otherwise, the addressis wrapped around to 0x0000_0000 during a 4-word burst transfer. As a result, the datastructure of LLI nodes cannot be stored in a continuous address area.If the LLI field is set to 0, the current node is at the end of the linked list. In this case, thecorresponding channel is disabled after the corresponding data blocks of the current node aretransferred.

Member.name: lli
Member.description: LLI. The bit[31:2] of the next LLI node address and the address bit[1:0] are both set to 0. A linked list address must be 4-byte aligned.

Member.name: r
Member.description: Reserved. This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: lm
Member.description:
Master for loading the next LLI node.
0: Master1
1: Master2

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CN_CONTROL
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_Cn_CONTROL is a DMAC channel control register. Its offset address is 0x10C + n x0x20. The value of n ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 map to DMA channels 0–3.

Member.name: i
Member.description:
Terminal count interrupt enable. This bit determines whether the current LLI node triggers a terminal count interrupt.
0: not trigger
1: trigger

Member.name: prot
Member.description: HPROT[2:0] access protection signal transmitted by the Master.

Member.name: di
Member.description:
Destination address increment.
0: The destination address is not incremented
1: The destination address is incremented once after a data segment is transferred
If the destination device is a peripheral, the destination address is not incremented. If the destination device is a memory, the destination address is incremented.

Member.name: si
Member.description:
Source address increment.
0: The source address is not incremented
1: The source address is incremented once after a data segment is transferred
If the source device is a peripheral, the source address is not incremented. If the source device is a memory, the source address is incremented.

Member.name: d
Member.description:
Master for accessing the destination device.
0: The SIO, UART0, UART1, UART2, SSP1, and SSP0 access the destination device using Master1.
1: The SPI flash, NAND flash, and DDRC access the destination device using Master 2.

Member.name: s
Member.description:
Master for accessing the source device.
0: The SIO, UART0, UART1, UART2, SSP1, and SSP0 access the source device using Master1.
1: The SPI flash, NAND flash, and DDRC access the source device using Master2.

Member.name: dwidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the destination device.
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the Master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. The hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For details about the mapping between the value of DWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-26.

Member.name: swidth
Member.description:
Transfer bit width of the source device.
The transfer bit width is invalid if it is greater than the bit width of the Master.
The data widths of the destination and source devices can be different. The hardware automatically packs and unpacks the data.
For details about the mapping between the value of SWidth and the bit width, see Table 3-26.

Member.name: dbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the destination device.
Indicates the number of data segments to be transferred by the destination device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCnBREQ is valid.
This value must be set to a burst size supported by the destination device. If the destination device is a memory, the value is set to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For details about the mapping between the value of DBSize and the transfer size, see Table 3-25.

Member.name: sbsize
Member.description:
Burst size of the source device.
Indicates the number of data segments to be transferred by the source device in a burst transfer, that is, the number of transferred data segments when DMACCnBREQ is valid.
The value must be set to a burst size supported by the source device. If the source device is a memory, the value is set to the storage area size beyond the storage address boundary.
For details about the mapping between the value of SBSize and the transfer length, see Table 3-25.

Member.name: transfersize
Member.description:
The DMA transfer size can be configured by writing to DMAC_Cn_CONTROL only when the DMAC is a flow controller. The transfer size indicates the number of the data segments to be transferred by the source device.
When DMAC_Cn_CONTROL is read, the number of data segments transferred through the bus connected to the destination device is obtained.
When a channel is active, no valid information is obtained when this register is read. This is because that after software obtains the register value, the value changes during data transfer. Therefore, the register is read after the channel is enabled and data transfer is stopped.

RegisterGroup.name: DMAC_CN_CONFIG
RegisterGroup.description: DMAC_Cn_CONFIG is a DMAC channel configuration register. Its offset address is 0x110 +n x 0x20. The value of n ranges from 0 to 3. The values 0–3 map to DMA channels 0–3.This register is not updated when a new LLI node is loaded.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: h
Member.description:
Halt bit.
0: The DMA request is allowed.
1: The subsequent DMA requests are ignored and the contents in the channel FIFO are completely transferred.
This bit can disable a DMA channel without data loss by working with the Active bit and the Channel Enable bit.

Member.name: a
Member.description:
Active bit.
0: There is no data in the channel FIFO.
1: There is data in the channel FIFO.
This bit can disable a DMA channel without data loss by working with the Halt bit and Channel Enable bit.

Member.name: l
Member.description:
Lock bit.
0: Disable lock transfer on the bus.
1: Enable lock transfer on the bus.

Member.name: itc
Member.description:
Terminal count interrupt mask bit.
0: Mask the terminal count interrupts of the channel.
1: Do not mask the terminal count interrupts of the channel.

Member.name: ie
Member.description:
Error interrupt mask bit.
0: Mask the error interrupts of the channel.
1: Do not mask the error interrupts of the channel.

Member.name: flow_cntrl
Member.description:
Flow control and transfer type field.
This field is used to specify the flow controller and transfer type. The flow controller can be the DMAC, source device, or destination device.
The transfer type can be memory to peripheral, peripheral to memory, peripheral to peripheral, or memory to memory. For details, see Table 3-28.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: dest_peripheral
Member.description:
Destination device. This field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal of the DMA destination device of the channel.
If the destination device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
This bit must be 0 during writes and must be masked during reads.

Member.name: src_peripheral
Member.description:
Source device. This field is used to select a peripheral request signal as the request signal of the DMA source device of the channel.
If the source device for DMA transfer is a memory, this field is ignored.

Member.name: e
Member.description:
Channel enable bit. The current status of a channel can be queried by reading this register or DMAC_ENBLD_CHNS.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Clearing this bit can disable a channel. When this bit is cleared, the current bus transfer continues until the data transfer is complete. Then, the channel is disabled and the remaining data in the FIFO is lost. When the last LLI is transferred or an error occurs during transfer, the channel is also disabled and this bit is cleared. If you want to disable a channel without data loss, the Halt bit must be set to 1 so the subsequent DMA requests are ignored by the channel. After this, the Active bit must be polled until its value becomes 0. This indicates that there is no data in the channel FIFO. At this time, the Enable bit can be cleared.
To enable a channel by setting this bit to 1, you must reinitialize the channel. If a channel is enabled by setting this bit to 1 only, unexpected results may occur.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_IRQSTATUS
RegisterGroup.description: INT_IRQSTATUS is the IRQ interrupt status register.

Member.name: irqstatus
Member.description:
Status of the IRQ interrupt source.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An IRQ interrupt is generated and sent to the processor.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_FIQSTATUS
RegisterGroup.description: INT_FIQSTATUS is the FIQ interrupt status register. The 32 bits of INT_INTENABLE map to 32 interrupt sources.

Member.name: fiqstatus
Member.description:
Status of the FIQ interrupt source.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An FIQ interrupt is generated and sent to the processor.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_RAWINTR
RegisterGroup.description: INT_RAWINTR is the raw interrupt status register. It shows the status of raw interrupt requests and the status of the software interrupts that are generated by configuring INT_SOFTINT. The 32 bits of INT_RAWINTR map to 32 interrupt sources.

Member.name: rawinterrupt
Member.description:
Status of the interrupt requests of raw interrupt sources.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_INTSELECT
RegisterGroup.description: INT_INTSELECT is the interrupt source select register. It determines whether the selected interrupt sources generate IRQ interrupts or FIQ interrupts. The 32 bits of INT_INTSELECT map to 32 interrupt sources.

Member.name: intselect
Member.description:
Interrupt request type of interrupt sources.
0: IRQ interrupt
1: FIQ interrupt

RegisterGroup.name: INT_INTENABLE
RegisterGroup.description: INT_INTENABLE is the interrupt enable register. It is used to enable interrupt request lines. After reset, the value of INT_INTENABLE is changed to 0x0000_0000. As a result, all interrupt sources are masked. The 32 bits of INT_INTENABLE map to 32 interrupt sources.

Member.name: intenable
Member.description:
Returned mask status of each interrupt source when this register is read.
0: masked
1: not masked
Interrupt source is enabled bit by bit when this register is written.
0: The current value of the corresponding bit is not affected.
1: The corresponding bit is set to 1 to enable the corresponding interrupt request.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_INTENCLEAR
RegisterGroup.description: INT_INTENCLEAR is the interrupt enable clear register. It is used to clear the corresponding bits of INT_INTENABLE. INT_INTENCLEAR is write-only and has no default reset value.

Member.name: intenableclear
Member.description:
Mask of the interrupt source corresponding to INT_INTENABLE.
0: The current value of the corresponding bit of INT_INTENABLE is not affected.
1: The corresponding bit of INT_INTENABLE is cleared and the corresponding interrupt request is masked.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_SOFTINT
RegisterGroup.description: INT_SOFTINT is the software interrupt register. Through software, it controls whether to generate interrupts by the interrupt source input lines. The software interrupts can be cleared by writing INT_SOFTINTCLEAR. The clear operation is performed after the ISR is executed.

Member.name: softint
Member.description:
Generates a raw software interrupt on a specified interrupt source.
0: The current value of the corresponding bit is not affected.
1: The corresponding bit is set to 1 and a software interrupt request is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_SOFTINTCLEAR
RegisterGroup.description: INT_SOFTINTCLEAR is the software interrupt clear register. It is used to clear the corresponding bit of INT_SOFTINT. INT_SOFTINTCLEAR is write-only and has no default reset value.

Member.name: softintclear
Member.description:
Mask of the interrupt request corresponding to INT_SOFTINT.
00: The corresponding bit of INT_SOFTINT is not affected.
1: The corresponding bit of INT_SOFTINT is cleared and the corresponding interrupt request is masked.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_PROTECTION
RegisterGroup.description:
INT_PROTECTION is the protection enable register It is used to enable or disable the accessto the protected registers.CAUTION
  • After reset, this register is cleared and the registers of the INT can be accessed in both usermode and privileged mode.
  • When the CPU cannot generate the correct protection information (HPROT), the registersof the INT can be accessed in user mode after INT_PROTECTION is reset.

Member.name: protection
Member.description:
Register access protection enable.
0: disabled. The registers of the INT can be accessed both in user mode and privileged mode.
1: enabled. The registers of the INT can be access in privileged mode only.

RegisterGroup.name: SPI_CLK_DIV
RegisterGroup.description: SPI_CLK_DIV is the SPI clock ratio register.

Member.name: spi_clk_div
Member.description:
SPI clock ratio. The SPI clock frequency cannot be higher than 20 MHz. The value 12 MHz is recommended.
The field value ranges from 1 to 255. The value of spi_clk_div is used to define the SPI RX and RX bit rates. The formula is as follows: FSPICLK = FAPBCLK/2 x (spi_clk_div + 1)FAPBCLK is the APB clock frequency. If the APB clock is 120 MHz and the expected SPI clock is 12 MHz, the configured value of spi_clk_div is calculated as follows: (120/12)/2 –1 = 4

RegisterGroup.name: SPI_RW
RegisterGroup.description: SPI_RW is the SPI read/write register.

Member.name: spi_busy
Member.description:
SPI read/write status indicator.
0: The SPI is idle, and a new read/write operation can be initiated over the SPI.
1: A read/write operation is being performed over the SPI, and no new operation is allowed.

Member.name: spi_start
Member.description: SPI read/write start. Writing 1 automatically clears this field. Writing has no effect when spi_busy is 1. That is, no new SPI operation is started before the previous read/write operation is complete. If a start request is sent, hardware ignores this request.

Member.name: spi_rw
Member.description:
SPI operation type.
0: write
1: read

Member.name: spi_add
Member.description:
SPI operation address.
The address range is 0–127.

Member.name: spi_rdata
Member.description: Data read from the SPI.

Member.name: spi_wdata
Member.description: Data to be written to the SPI.

RegisterGroup.name: CONVER_T

Member.description:
Temperature sensor measurement start. This field must be set to 1.
1: starts. Hardware automatically sets this field to 0 when the interrupt is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: CRC_EN

Member.description:
Temperature sensor measurement CRC check enable.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_MASK

Member.name: int_mask
Member.description:
Temperature sensor measurement interrupt mask.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_CLEAR
RegisterGroup.description: INT_CLEAR is the temperature sensor measurement interrupt clear register.

Member.name: int_clear
Member.description:
Temperature sensor measurement interrupt clear.
Writing 1 clears the interrupt. Hardware automatically sets this field to 0 after the interrupt is cleared.

RegisterGroup.name: BUSY
RegisterGroup.description: BUSY is the temperature sensor measurement status register.

Member.name: busy
Member.description:
Temperature sensor measurement status.
0: ready
1: busy

RegisterGroup.name: INT_RAW
RegisterGroup.description: INT_RAW is the raw temperature sensor measurement interrupt status register.

Member.name: int_err
Member.description: Error interrupt.

Member.name: get_tmprt_int

RegisterGroup.name: INT_TCAP

Masked interrupt status.

RegisterGroup.name: T_VALUE

RegisterGroup.name: FILTER_NUM

RegisterGroup.name: TOT_OFFSET_L
RegisterGroup.description: TOT_OFFSET_L is the lower-8-bit corrected tot_offset register when the correctionalgorithm is used.

Member.description: Corrected tot_offset by using the correction algorithm. The value is expressed by complement codes –256 to +255. That is, tot_offset is 1990 + (–256 to +255) in the correction algorithm. This field value is the lower seven bits of tot_offset.

RegisterGroup.name: TOT_OFFSET_H
RegisterGroup.description: TOT_OFFSET_H is the upper-1-bit corrected tot_offset register when the correctionalgorithm is used.

Member.name: tot_offset_h
Member.description: Corrected tot_offset by using the correction algorithm. The value is expressed by complement codes –256 to +255. That is, tot_offset is 1990 + (–256 to +255) in the correction algorithm. This field value is the upper one bit of tot_offset.

RegisterGroup.name: TEMP_OFFSET
RegisterGroup.description: TEMP_OFFSET is the temperature code word offset register corresponding to the correctioninput LUT.

Member.name: temp_offset
Member.description: Offset of the temperature code words that are input to the correction LUT. The value is expressed by the complement code and the value ranges from –32 to +31.

RegisterGroup.name: OUTSIDE_TEMP
RegisterGroup.description: OUTSIDE_TEMP is the external SAR ADC temperature register.

Member.name: outside_temp
Member.description: Temperature provided by the external SAR ADC. The code word indicates –40°C to +140°C.

RegisterGroup.name: DIE_TEMP
RegisterGroup.description: DIE_TEMP is the RTC internal t_sensor temperature register.

Member.name: die_temp
Member.description: Temperature provided by the internal t_sensor. The code word indicates –40°C to +140°C.

RegisterGroup.name: TEMP_SEL
RegisterGroup.description: TEMP_SEL is the correction algorithm input temperature source select register.

Member.name: fix_mode
Member.description:
Correction algorithm input temperature source select.
0: temp_sel
1: external

Member.name: temp_sel
Member.description:
Correction algorithm input temperature source select.
When fix_mode is 0 and ISO is 1:
0: internal
1: external
When fix_mode is 0 and ISO is 0, the internal temperature is always used; when fix_mode is 1, the external temperature is always used.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description: SC_CTRL is a system control register. It is used to specify the operations that are performedby the system.CAUTIONWrite protection for this register can be enabled by configuring SC_LOCKEN. This registercan be written only when write protection is disabled.

Member.name: wdogenov
Member.description:
Watchdog count clock select.
0: 3 MHz clock
1: bus clock

Member.name: timeren3ov
Member.description:
Count clock select of timer3.
0: 3 MHz clock.
1: bus clock

Member.name: timeren2ov
Member.description:
Count clock select of timer2.
0: 3 MHz clock
1: bus clock

Member.name: timeren1ov
Member.description:
Count clock select of timer1.
0: 3 MHz clock
1: bus clock

Member.name: timeren0ov
Member.description:
Count clock select of timer0.
0: 3 MHz clock
1: bus clock

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0 and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.name: remapstat
Member.description:
Status of address remap.
0: The address is not remapped.
1: The address is remapped. The details are as follows:
NANDC or SFC is remapped to address 0.

Member.name: remapclear
Member.description:
Address remap clear.
0: keep the remap status
1: clear the remap status
For details about the address mappings before and after remapping is cleared, see Table 1-1.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this bit returns 0 and writing to this bit has no effect.

Member.name: modestatus
Member.description:
Mode status. The current operating mode of the system is returned.
0x0: reserved
0x1: doze
0x2: slow
0x3: XTAL CTL
0x4: normal
0x6: PLL CTL
0x9: SW from XTAL
0xA: SW from PLL
0xB: SW to XTAL
0xE: SW to PLL
Other values: reserved

Member.name: modectrl
Member.description:
Mode control. This field defines the operating mode to which the system controller is switched.
000: reserved
001: doze
010: slow
100: normal

RegisterGroup.name: SC_SYSRES
RegisterGroup.description: SC_SYSRES is a system soft reset register. When any value is written to this register, thesystem controller transmits a system soft reset request to the reset module. Then the resetmodule resets the system.CAUTIONWrite protection for this register can be enabled by configuring SC_LOCKEN. This registercan be written only when write protection is disabled.

Member.name: softresreq
Member.description: The system is reset when any value is written to this register.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_IMCTRL
RegisterGroup.description: SC_IMCTRL is an interrupt mode control register. It is used to control the system mode whenan interrupt is generated.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0x000000 and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.name: inmdtype
Member.description:
Type of the interrupt for triggering the interrupt mode of the system.
0: fast interrupt request (FIQ) interrupt
1: FIQ interrupt or interrupt request (IRQ) interrupt

Member.name: itmdctrl
Member.description:
Operating mode of the system with the lowest speed in interrupt mode. The value obtained after the values of this register and SC_CTRL[modectrl] are ORed indicates the operating mode of the system after an interrupt is generated. The definitions of these bits are as follows:
000: sleep
001: doze
01X: slow
1XX: normal

Member.name: itmden
Member.description:
Interrupt mode enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled. When an interrupt is generated, the system enters the interrupt mode.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_IMSTAT
RegisterGroup.description: SC_IMSTAT is an interrupt mode status register. It is used to check whether the system is ininterrupt mode. The system can be set to the interrupt mode forcibly by configuring thisregister.CAUTIONWhen the interrupt service routine (ISR) ends, the interrupt mode must be cleared manually.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0x00000000 and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.name: itmdstat
Member.description:
Interrupt mode status. The bit is used by software for controlling whether the system enters the interrupt mode.
When the register is read:
0: The system is not in interrupt mode.
1: The system is in interrupt mode.
When the register is written:
0: Software controls whether the system enters the interrupt mode.
1: Software does not control whether the system enters the interrupt mode.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_XTALCTRL
RegisterGroup.description: SC_XTALCTRL is a crystal oscillator control register. It is used to specify the stable waittime after the clock module is initialized. The stable wait time is the period when the systemis switched from the XTAL CTL mode to the SW-to-XTAL mode.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns 0x0000 and writing to this field has no effect.

Member.name: xtaltime
Member.description:
Wait time of crystal oscillator switching.
The value of this field is used to specify the time spent on switching the system mode from XTAL CTL to SW-to-XTAL. The wait cycle can be calculated as follows: (65536 – xtaltime) x T46.8 K. T46.8 K indicates the clock cycle of the 46.8 kHz clock.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this bit returns 0x0 and writing to this bit has no effect.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this field returns the written value and writing to this field has no effect.

RegisterGroup.name: SC_PLLCTRL
RegisterGroup.description: SC_PLLCTRL is a PLL control register. It is used to control whether to enable the on-chipARMPLL through software or system mode switching. It also sets the stable time of theARMPLL.CAUTIONWrite protection for this register can be enabled by configuring SC_LOCKEN. This registercan be written only when write protection is disabled.When the ARMPLL is enabled by switching the system mode (namely, by configuringSC_PLLCTRL[pllover]), the ARMPLL is disabled automatically if the system is not innormal mode.The clock frequency of the APLL is controlled by PERI_CRG0 and PERI_CRG1. When thePLL frequency is changed, a stable clock can be output only after 0.5 ms. Therefore, theplltime of this register must meet this requirement.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this bit returns 0x0 and writing to this bit has no effect.

Member.name: plltime
Member.description:
Stable time of the ARMPLL.
This time refers to the period from the start of the PLL to the output of a stable PLL clock. That is, the wait time of switching the system mode from PLL CTL to SW-to-PLL. The timeout is calculated as follows: 4 x (33554432 – plltime) x TXIN. TXIN indicates the clock cycle of the external crystal oscillator of the Hi3518.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. Reading this bit returns 0x0 and writing to this bit has no effect.

Member.name: pllover
Member.description:
Whether the ARMPLL is enabled is controlled by the software rather than system mode switching.
This bit must be set to 0.
0: The ARMPLL is enabled by switching the system mode.
1: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: PERIPHCTRL0
RegisterGroup.description: PERIPHCTRL0 is peripheral control register 0.CAUTIONWrite protection for this register can be enabled by configuring SC_LOCKEN. This register

Member.name: arm_tcm_gate_en

0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: arm_mem_adjust
Member.description: ARM9 memory adjustment.

Member.name: global_software_int
Member.description:
Global software interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: ddrc_apb_gt_en
Member.description:
DDRC APB clock gating.
0: disabled

RegisterGroup.name: SC_LOCKEN
RegisterGroup.description: SC_LOCKEN is a register for locking key system control registers.

Member.name: scper_lockl
Member.description:
Register for locking key system control registers. The key registers include SC_CTRL, SYSSTAT, and SC_PLLCTRL.
When 0x1ACC_E551 is written to SC_LOCKEN, the write permission for all registers is enabled; when any other value is written to SC_LOCKEN, the write permission is disabled.
Reading this register returns the lock status rather than its written value.
0x0000_0000: The write permission is enabled (unlocked).
0x0000_0001: The write permission is disabled (locked).
