Member.description: Write ODT: specifies whether ODT should be enabled ('1') or disabled ('0') on each of at most four ranks when a write command is sent to rank n. WRODT0, WRODT1, WRODT2, and WRODT3 specify ODT settings when a write is to rank 0, rank 1, rank 2, and rank 3 respectively. The four bits of each field each represent a rank, the LSB being rank 0 and the MSB being rank 3. The ODT is enabled only on the rank that is being written to by default.

Member.name: rdodt3
Member.description:
Read ODT: rank select. The description is the same as rodt0.
Note: The actual reset value is calculated based on the configured number of ranks. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: rdodt2
Member.description:
Read ODT: rank select. The description is the same as rodt0.
Note: The actual reset value is calculated based on the configured number of ranks. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: rdodt1
Member.description: Read ODT: rank select. The description is the same as rodt0.

Member.name: rdodt0
Member.description: Read ODT: specifies whether ODT should be enabled ('1') or disabled ('0') on each of at most four ranks when a read command is sent to rank n. RDODT0, RDODT1, RDODT2, and RDODT3 specify ODT settings when a read is to rank 0, rank 1, rank 2, and rank 3 respectively. The four bits of each field each represent a rank, the LSB being rank 0 and the MSB being rank 3. The ODT is disabled during reads by default.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DTAR
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DTAR is a data training address register.

Member.name: dtmpr
Member.description:
Data training using MPR (only for DDR3).
If this bit is set, the SDRAM multi-purpose register (MPR) should be used during data training. Otherwise, data training is performed by first writing to some locations in the SDRAM and then reading them back.

Member.name: dtbank
Member.description:
Data training bank address.
This field is used to select the SDRAM bank address to be used during data training.

Member.name: dtrow
Member.description:
Data training row address.
This field is used to select the SDRAM row address to be used during data training.

Member.name: dtcol
Member.description:
Data training column address.
This field is used to select the SDRAM column address to be used during data training. The lower four bits of this address must always be "0000".

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DTDR0
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DTDR0 is data training data register 0.

Member.name: dtbyte3
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the fourth byte of data used during data training. The same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

Member.name: dtbyte2
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the third byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

Member.name: dtbyte1
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the second byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

Member.name: dtbyte0
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the first byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DTDR1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DTDR1 is data training data register 1.

Member.name: dtbyte7
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the eighth byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

Member.name: dtbyte6
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the seventh byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

Member.name: dtbyte5
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the sixth byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

Member.name: dtbyte4
Member.description:
Data training data.
This field indicates the fifth byte of data used during data training. This same data byte is used for each byte lane. The default sequence is a walking 1 while data toggling every data cycle.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_CTRL0
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_CTRL0 is PUB DDR PHY I/O compensation configuration register 0.

Member.name: zqpd
Member.description:
ZQ power down.
0: normal mode
1: The ZQ PAD power supply is shut down to implement low-power control.

Member.name: zcal
Member.description:
Impedance calibration enable.
Writing 1 enables the impedance auto-calibration logic. This field is automatically cleared after calibration.

Member.name: zcalbyp
Member.description:
Impedance compensation bypass mode.
0: automatic
1: ZQ auto-calibration is disabled. Calibration can be manually enabled.

Member.name: zden
Member.description:
Impedance compensation mode.
0: auto-compensation mode
1: customer-specific mode

Member.name: zdata
Member.description:
Impedance calibration configuration.
zdata[27:20]: reserved
zdata[19:15]: ODT pull-up impedance
zdata[14:10]: ODT pull-down impedance
zdata[9:5]: output pull-up impedance
zdata[4:0]: output pull-down impedance

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_CTRL1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_CTRL1 is PUB DDR PHY I/O compensation configuration register 1.

Member.name: zprog_odt
Member.description: I/O matched impedance divide ratio select.

Member.name: zprog_drv
Member.description: I/O drive impedance divide ratio select.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_STATUS0
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_STATUS0 is DDR PHY I/O compensation status register 0.

Member.name: zdone
Member.description:
Impedance calibration completion indicator.
0: Impedance calibration does not start or impedance is being calibrated.
1: Impedance calibration is complete.

Member.name: zerr
Member.description:
Impedance calibration error indicator.
0: normal
1: error

Member.name: zctrl
Member.description:
Impedance calibration configuration.
zctrl[27:20]: reserved
zctrl[19:15]: ODT pull-up impedance
zctrl[14:10]: ODT pull-down impedance
zctrl[9:5]: output pull-up impedance
zctrl[4:0]: output pull-down impedance

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_STATUS1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_ZQ_STATUS1 is DDR PHY I/O compensation status register 1.

Member.name: opu
Member.description:
ODT impedance pull-up calibration status.
00: Impedance calibration is complete and no error occurs.
01: An overflow error occurs.
10: An underflow error occurs.
11: Calibration is in progress.

Member.name: opd
Member.description:
ODT impedance pull-down calibration status.
00: Impedance calibration is complete and no error occurs.
01: An overflow error occurs.
10: An underflow error occurs.
11: Calibration is in progress.

Member.name: zpu
Member.description:
Output impedance pull-up calibration status.
00: Impedance calibration is complete and no error occurs.
01: An overflow error occurs.
10: An underflow error occurs.
11: Calibration is in progress.

Member.name: zpd
Member.description:
Output impedance pull-down calibration status.
00: Impedance calibration is complete and no error occurs.
01: An overflow error occurs.
10: An underflow error occurs.
11: Calibration is in progress.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DXNGCR
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DXNGCR is a DATX8 general configuration register.

Member.name: rttoal
Member.description:
RTT on additive latency.
This bit indicates the time when the ODT control of DQ/DQS SSTL I/Os is set to the value in DQODT/DQSODT during read cycles.
0: ODT control is set to DQSODT/DQODT almost two cycles before read data preamble
1: ODT control is set to DQSODT/DQODT almost one cycle before read data preamble

Member.name: rttoh
Member.description:
RTT output hold.
This field indicates the number of clock cycles (from 0 to 3) after the read data postamble during which ODT control should retain DQSODT for DQS or DQODT for DQ/DM before it is disabled (setting it to '0') when dynamic ODT control is used. ODT is disabled almost RTTOH clock cycles after the read postamble.

Member.name: dqrtt
Member.description:
DQ dynamic RTT control.
If this bit is set, the ODT control of DQ/DM SSTL I/Os is dynamically controlled by setting it to the value in DQODT during reads and disabling it (setting it to '0') during any other cycle. If this bit is not set, the ODT control of DQ SSTL I/Os is always set to the value in DQODT.

Member.name: dqsrtt
Member.description:
DQS dynamic RTT control.
If this bit is set, the ODT control of DQS SSTL I/Os is dynamically controlled by setting it to the value in DQSODT during reads and disabling it (setting it to '0') during any other cycle. If this bit is not set, the ODT control of DQS SSTL I/Os is always set to the value in DQSODT field.

Member.name: dsen
Member.description:
Write DQS enable.
This field is used to control whether the write DQS going to the SDRAM is enabled (toggling) or disabled (static value) and whether the DQS is inverted. DQS# is always the inversion of DQS. These values are valid only when DQS/DQS# output enable is on; otherwise, the DQS/DQS# is tristated.
00: DQS disabled (driven to constant 0)
01: DQS toggling with inverted polarity
10: DQS toggling with normal polarity (This should be the default setting)
11: DQS disabled (driven to constant 1)

Member.name: dqsrpd
Member.description:
DQSR power down.
If this bit is set, the PDQSR cell is powered down.

Member.name: dxpdr
Member.description:
Data power down receiver.
If this bit is set, the input receiver on I/O is powered down for DQ, DM, and DQS/DQS# pins of the byte.

Member.name: dxpdd
Member.description:
Data power down driver.
If this bit is set, the output driver on I/O is powered down for DQ, DM, and DQS/DQS# pins of the byte.

Member.name: dxiom
Member.description:
Data I/O mode.
This bit is used to select the SSTL mode (when set to 0) or CMOS mode (when set to 1) of the I/O for DQ, DM, and DQS/DQS# pins of the byte.

Member.name: dqodt
Member.description:
Data on-die termination.
If this bit is set, the on-die termination on the I/O is enabled for DQ and DM pins of the byte.

Member.name: dqsodt
Member.description:
DQS on-die termination.
If this bit is set, the on-die termination on the I/O is enabled for DQS/DQS# pin of the byte.

Member.name: dxen
Member.description:
Data byte enable.
If this bit is set, the DATX8 and SSTL I/Os used on the data byte are enabled. Setting this bit to '0' disables the byte. For example, the byte SSTL I/Os enter the power-down mode and the DLL in the DATX8 enters the bypass mode.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DXNGSR0
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DXNGSR0 is DATX8 general status register 0.

Member.name: dtpass
Member.description:
Data training pass count.
This field indicates the number of passing configurations during DQS gate training. Bits [2:0] are for rank 0, bits [5:3] for rank 1, and so on.

Member.name: dtierr
Member.description:
Data training intermittent error.
If this field is set, there is an intermittent error during data training of the byte. For example, a pass is followed by a failure and then another pass. Bit [0] is for rank 0, bit 1 for rank 1, and so on.

Member.name: dterr
Member.description:
Data training error.
If this field is set, a valid DQS gating window cannot be found during data training of the byte. Bit [0] is for rank 0, bit 1 for rank 1, and so on.

Member.name: dtdone
Member.description:
Data training done.
If this field is set, the byte has finished data training. Bit [0] is for rank 0, bit 1 for rank 1, and so on.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DXNGSR1
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DXNGSR1 is DATX8 general status register 1.

Member.name: dqsdft
Member.description:
DQS drift.
This field is used to report the drift on the read data strobe of the data byte.
00: no drift
01: 90° drift
10: 180° drift
11: 270° drift or more
Bits [1:0] are for rank 0, bits [3:2] for rank 1, and so on.

Member.name: dfterr
Member.description:
DQS drift error.
If this field is set, the byte read data strobe has drifted by more than or equal to the drift limit configured in the PHY general configuration register (PGCR). Bit [0] is for rank 0, bit 1 for rank 1, and so on.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DXNDLLCR
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DXNDLLCR is a DATX8 DLL control register.

Member.name: dlldis
Member.description:
DLL disable.
A disabled DLL is bypassed. The default value 0 indicates that the DLL is enabled.

Member.name: dllsrst
Member.description:
DLL soft reset.
This bit is used to soft-reset the byte DLL by driving the DLL soft reset pin.

Member.name: sdlbmode
Member.description:
Slave DLL loopback mode.
If this bit is set, the slave DLL enters the loopback mode in which there is no 90? phase shift on read DQS/DQS#. This bit must be set when the byte PHYs are operated in loopback mode such as during BIST loopback. This bit applies only to the PHYs that have this feature. For details, see the PHY data book.

Member.name: atesten
Member.description:
Analog test enable.
This bit is used to enable the analog test signal to be output on the DLL analog test output (test_out_a). The DLL analog test output is tristated when this bit is 0.

Member.name: sdphase
Member.description:
Slave DLL phase trim.
This field is used to select the phase difference between the input clock and the corresponding output clock of the slave DLL.
0000: 90
0001: 72
0010: 54
0011: 36
0100: 108
0101: 90
0110: 72
0111: 54
1000: 126
1001: 108
1010: 90
1011: 72
1100: 144
1101: 126
1110: 108
1111: 90

Member.name: sstart
Member.description:
Slave auto startup.
This field is used to control how the slave DLL starts up relative to the master DLL locking:
0X: Slave DLL automatically starts up once the master DLL is locked.
10: The automatic startup of the slave DLL is disabled, and the phase detector is disabled.
11: The automatic startup of the slave DLL is disabled, and the phase detector is enabled.

Member.name: mfwdly
Member.description:
Master feed-forward delay trim.
This field is used to trim the delay in the master DLL feed-forward path.
000: minimum delay
111: maximum delay

Member.name: mfbdly
Member.description:
Master feedback delay trim.
This field is used to trim the delay in the master DLL feedback path.
000: minimum delay
111: maximum delay

Member.name: sfwdly
Member.description:
Slave feed-forward delay trim.
This field is used to trim the delay in the slave DLL feed-forward path.
000: minimum delay
111: maximum delay

Member.name: sfbdly
Member.description:
Slave feed-back delay trim.
This field is used to trim the delay in the slave DLL feedback path.
000: minimum delay
111: maximum delay

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DXNDQTR
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DXNDQTR is a DATX8 DQ timing register.

Member.name: dqdly7
Member.description:
DQ7 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly6
Member.description:
DQ6 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly5
Member.description:
DQ5 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly4
Member.description:
DQ4 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly3
Member.description:
DQ3 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly2
Member.description:
DQ2 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly1
Member.description:
DQ1 delay.
The description is the same as DQ0 delay.

Member.name: dqdly0
Member.description:
DQ0 delay.
This field is used to adjust the delay of the data relative to the nominal delay that matches the delay of the data strobes through the slave DLL and clock tree. Every four bits of this register control the delay of a different data bit in the byte. DQDLY0 controls the delay of data bit [0], DQDLY1 controls data bit [1], and so on. The lower two bits of the DQDLY for each DQ bit controls the delay for the data clocked by DQS, while the upper two bits control the delay for the data clocked by DQS_b. The following are valid settings for each 2-bit control field:
00: nominal delay
01: nominal delay + 1 step
10: nominal delay + 2 steps
11: nominal delay + 3 steps
Note: The step size can be queried in the data books of compatible DWC DDR PHYs.

RegisterGroup.name: DDRC_PUB_DXNDQSTR
RegisterGroup.description: DDRC_PUB_DXNDQSTR is a DATX8 DQS timing register.

Member.name: dmdly
Member.description:
DM delay.
This field is used to adjust the delay of the data mask relative to the nominal delay that matches the delay of the data strobes through the slave DLL and clock tree. The lower two bits of the DQMDLY controls the delay for the data clocked by DQS, while the upper two bits control the delay for the data clocked by DQS_b. The following are valid settings for each 2-bit control field:
00: nominal delay
01: nominal delay + 1 step
10: nominal delay + 2 steps
11: nominal delay + 3 steps
Note: The step size can be queried in the data books of compatible DWC DDR PHYs.

Member.name: dqsndly
Member.description:
DQS# delay.
This field is used to adjust the delay of the data strobes relative to the nominal delay that matches the delay of the data bit through the slave DLL and clock tree. DQSDLY controls the delay on DQS strobe and DQSNDLY controls the delay on DQS#.
000: nominal delay ? 3 steps
001: nominal delay ? 2 steps
010: nominal delay ? 1 step
011: nominal delay
100: nominal delay + 1 step
101: nominal delay + 2 steps
110: nominal delay + 3 steps
111: nominal delay + 4 steps
Note: The step size can be queried in the data books of compatible DWC DDR PHYs.

Member.name: dqsdly
Member.description:
DQS.
This field is used to adjust the delay of the data strobes relative to the nominal delay that matches the delay of the data bit through the slave DLL and clock tree. DQSDLY controls the delay on DQS strobe and DQSNDLY controls the delay on DQS#.
000: nominal delay ? 3 steps
001: nominal delay ? 2 steps
010: nominal delay ? 1 step
011: nominal delay
100: nominal delay + 1 step
101: nominal delay + 2 steps
110: nominal delay + 3 steps
111: nominal delay + 4 steps
Note: The step size can be queried in the data books of compatible DWC DDR PHYs.

Member.name: r3dgps
Member.description:
Rank 3 DQS gating phase select.
The description is the same as r0dgps.
Note: The actual reset value is calculated based on the configured number of ranks. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: r2dgps
Member.description:
Rank 2 DQS gating phase select.
The description is the same as r0dgps.
Note: The actual reset value is calculated based on the configured number of ranks. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: r1dgps
Member.description:
Rank 1 DQS gating phase select.
The description is the same as r0dgps. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: r0dgps
Member.description:
Rank 0 DQS gating phase select.
This field is used to select the clock used to enable the data strobes during read, so that the value of the data strobes before and after the preamble/postamble are filtered out. The RnDGPS fields are initially set by the PUBL during automatic DQS data training and subsequently updated during data strobe drift compensation. However, these values can be overwritten by a direct write to this register, and the automatic update during DQS drift compensation can be disabled using the PHY general configuration register (PGCR). Every two bits of this register control the DQS gating for each of at most four ranks. R0DGPS controls the DQS gating for rank 0, R1DGPS controls rank 1, and so on. The following are valid values for each 2-bit RnDGPS field:
00: 90° clock (clk90)
01: 180° clock (clk180)
10: 270° clock (clk270)
11: 360° clock (clk0)

Member.name: r3dgsl
Member.description:
Rank 3 DQS gating system latency.
The description is the same as r0dgsl.
Note: The actual reset value is calculated based on the configured number of ranks. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: r2dgsl
Member.description:
Rank 2 DQS gating system latency.
The description is the same as r0dgsl.
Note: The actual reset value is calculated based on the configured number of ranks. The Hi3518 does not support the configuration.

Member.name: r1dgsl
Member.description:
Rank 1 DQS gating system latency.
The description is the same as r0dgsl.

Member.name: r0dgsl
Member.description:
Rank 0 DQS gating system latency.
This field is used to increase the number of clock cycles required for obtaining valid DDR read data. At most five extra clock cycles are supported. This is used to compensate for board delays and other system delays. The value 000 indicates power-on by default (for example, no extra clock cycles are required). The SL fields are initially set by the PUBL during automatic DQS data training but these values can be overwritten by a direct write to this register. Every three bits of this register control the latency of each of at most four ranks. R0DGSL controls the latency of rank 0, R1DGSL controls rank 1, and so on.
000: no extra clock cycles
001: 1 extra clock cycle
010: 2 extra clock cycles
011: 3 extra clock cycles
100: 4 extra clock cycles
101: 5 extra clock cycles
110: reserved
111: reserved

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_CON
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_CON is a NANDC configuration register.

Member.name: edo_en
Member.description:
NAND flash data read enable in EDO mode.
0: normal mode
1: EDO mode
This function must be used according to the requirements of specific memories.

Member.name: ecc_type
Member.description:
ECC mode select.
000: non-ECC mode
001: 1-bit mode
010: 4-bit mode
011: reserved
100: 24-bit mode for 1 KB
101–111: reserved
The reset value depends on the NFC_ECC_TYPE pin.

Member.name: rb_sel
Member.description:
This field is valid when multiple external NAND flash memories (multiple CSs) are connected.
0: The NAND flash memories share a ready/busy signal.
1: The NAND flash memories use their own ready/busy signals.
When only one NAND flash is connected, only CS0 and ready/busy 0 are used.

Member.name: cs_ctrl
Member.description:
CS control.
0: When the NAND flash is busy, the CS signal is fixed at 0.
1: When the NAND flash is busy, the CS signal is set to 1.
This mode maps to the "cs do not care" mode of the NAND flash.

Member.name: bus_width
Member.description:
Data line width of the NAND flash.
0: 8 bits.
1: 16 bits
The reset value depends on the NFC_BUS_WIDE pin.

Member.name: pagesize
Member.description:
Page size of the NAND flash.
01: 2 KB
10: 4 KB
11: 8 KB
Other values: reserved
The reset value depends on the NFC_PAGE_SIZE pin.

Member.name: op_mode
Member.description:
Operating mode of the NANDC.
0: boot mode
1: normal mode

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_PWIDTH
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_PWIDTH is a read/write pulse width configuration register.

Member.name: rw_hcnt
Member.description:
High-level width of the read/write signal of the NAND flash.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

Member.name: r_lcnt
Member.description:
Low-level width of the read signal of the NAND flash.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

Member.name: w_lcnt
Member.description:
Low-level width of the write signal of the NAND flash.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_OPIDLE
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_OPIDLE is an operation interval configuration register.

Member.name: frb_wait
Member.description: When a number of cycles are delayed after a read/write command is sent, the ready signal is detected to check whether it becomes high. The number of delay cycles is frb_wait x 8.

Member.name: cmd1_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after command 1 is sent.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

Member.name: addr_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after the address is sent.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

Member.name: write_data_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after data is written.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

Member.name: cmd2_wait
Member.description:
Number of wait cycles after command 2 is sent.
0x0–0xF: 1–16 clock cycles.

Member.name: frb_idle
Member.description:
A read signal can be sent only when a number of cycles are delayed after the ready signal of the NAND flash becomes high.
The number of delay cycles is frb_idle x 8.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_CMD
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_CMD is a command word configuration register.

Member.name: read_status_cmd
Member.description: Read status command word.

Member.name: cmd2
Member.description: Command 2 that is sent to the NAND flash by the NANDC.

Member.name: cmd1
Member.description: Command 1 that is sent to the NAND flash by the NANDC.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_ADDRL
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_ADDRL is a lower-bit address configuration register.

Member.name: addr_l
Member.description: Lower 32-bit address of the NAND flash.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_ADDRH
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_ADDRH is an upper-bit address configuration register.

Member.name: addr_h
Member.description: Upper 16-bit address of the NAND flash.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_DATA_NUM
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_DATA_NUM is a read/written data count configuration register.

Member.name: nfc_data_num
Member.description:
Number of data segments that are read and written randomly by the NANDC. The maximum value is 2368 bytes.
Note: This field is valid only when ecc_type is 00.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_OP
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_OP is an operation register.

Member.name: address_cycles
Member.description: Number of address cycles sent to the NAND flash.

Member.name: nf_cs
Member.description:
NAND flash CS signal select.
00: CS 0
01: CS 1
Other values: reserved

Member.name: cmd1_en
Member.description:
Command 1 transmit enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: addr_en
Member.description:
NAND flash address write enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: write_data_en
Member.description:
NAND flash data write enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: read_data_en and write_data_en cannot be 1 at the same time.

Member.name: cmd2_en
Member.description:
Command 2 transmit enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: wait_ready_en
Member.description:
Wait ready/busy high enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: read_data_en
Member.description:
NAND flash data read enable by starting to read the state machine.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: read_data_en and write_data_en cannot be 1 at the same time.

Member.name: read_status_en
Member.description:
When this bit is 1, the command 0x70 for reading the status is sent to the NAND flash and the status data is read from the NAND flash. After that, the returned data is written to the NFC_STATUS field of the NANDC status register instead of the internal buffer.
After the NAND flash is erased and programmed, the results need to be read to check whether the operations are successful. If this bit is enabled, the operations such as erasing and programming can be performed at a time, and the data indicating whether the operation is successful can be returned from the NAND flash. In this way, the CPU intervention is reduced.
Note: When read_data_en is 1, this bit is invalid.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_STATUS is a status register.

Member.name: nf_status
Member.description:
Status data read from the NAND flash.
This field is valid only when both NFC_OP[read_status] and NFC_STATUS[nfc_ready] are 1.

Member.name: nf1_ready
Member.description:
Status of the ready/busy signal of the NAND flash corresponding to CS 1.
This bit is valid when multiple flash memories are connected and they use their own ready_busy signals.
This is because multiple NAND flash memories share a ready/busy signal by default. The reset value of the bit is 0.

Member.name: nf0_ready
Member.description:
Status of the ready/busy signal of the NAND flash corresponding to CS 0.
This bit is valid when multiple flash memories are connected and they use their own ready_busy signals.
This is because multiple NAND flash memories share a ready/busy signal by default. The reset value of the bit is 0.

Member.name: nfc_ready
Member.description:
Status of the ready/busy signal of the NANDC.
0: The NANDC is working.
1: The operation is complete and the next command can be received.
When NFC_OP is written to start a NANDC operation, the bit is cleared automatically.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_INTEN
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_INTEN is an interrupt enable register.

Member.name: wr_lock_en
Member.description:
Lock address write error interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: ahb_op_en
Member.description:
CPU read/write NANDC buffer error interrupt enable when the NANDC is reading/writing data from/to the NAND flash.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: err_invalid
Member.description: Uncorrectable error interrupt.

Member.name: err_valid
Member.description: Correctable error interrupt.

Member.name: cs1_done_en
Member.description:
CS 1 ready/busy signal going high interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: cs0_done_en
Member.description:
CS 0 ready/busy signal going high interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: op_done_en
Member.description:
Current operation done enable of the NANDC.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_INTS
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_INTS is an interrupt status register.

Member.name: wr_lock_en
Member.description:
Interrupt generated when the lock address is written.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: ahb_op_en
Member.description:
Interrupt generated when the CPU reads and writes the NANDC buffer in the process of reading/writing data from/to the NAND flash by the NANDC.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: err_invalid
Member.description:
Uncorrectable error interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.
In 1-bit ECC mode, if errors occur in two or more bits in the checked 512-byte data, an interrupt is generated.
In 4-bit ECC mode, if errors occur in five or more bits in the checked 512-byte data, an interrupt is generated.
In 8-bit ECC mode, if errors occur in eight or more bits in the checked 512-byte data, an interrupt is generated.

Member.name: err_vavid
Member.description:
Correctable error interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.
In 1-bit ECC mode, if an error occurs in one bit in the checked 512-byte data, an interrupt is generated.
In 4-bit ECC mode, if errors occur in one to four bits in the checked 512-byte data, an interrupt is generated.
In 8-bit ECC mode, if errors occur in one to eight bits of the checked 512-byte data, an interrupt is generated.

Member.name: cs1_done
Member.description:
CS 1 ready/busy signal going high interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.
This bit is valid when two flash memories are connected and the two flash memories use their own ready/busy signals. Otherwise, the bit is fixed at 0.

Member.name: cs0_done
Member.description:
CS 0 ready/busy signal going high interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.
This bit is valid when two flash memories are connected and the two flash memories use their own ready/busy signals. Otherwise, the bit is fixed at 0.

Member.name: op_done
Member.description:
Current operation done interrupt of the NANDC.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.
After NFC_OP is written, the bit is automatically cleared.

Member.name: lock_excmd_en
Member.description:
Protection address write-protection enable according to the extended write command (new commands may be added to new memories).
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: lock_en
Member.description:
Flash lock enable. When this control bit is 1, if the erased or programmed address is between the start lock address and the end lock address, the erasing and programming operations are invalid.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: global_lock_en
Member.description:
Flash global lock enable. When this bit is 1, the NAND flash cannot be erased or programmed.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: lock_down
Member.description:
NAND flash lock mode.
0: lock mode
1: lock-down mode. After the value 1 is written, this bit cannot be written. In addition, this bit can be cleared only when a hard reset is performed.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_ECC_TEST
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_ECC_TEST is an ECC test register.

Member.name: ecc_mask
Member.description:
ECC function mask.
0: Whether the ECC check and correction are performed depends on the value of ecc_type.
1: The ECC check and correction are forbidden. The structure of the data read from or written to the NAND flash is still converted based on the format of ecc_type.

Member.name: dec_only
Member.description:
Decoding only enable.
When 1 is written to this bit, ECC decoding is enabled, but the NAND flash is not read or written.
When the bit is read, the value 0 is returned.

Member.name: enc_only
Member.description:
Encoding only enable.
When 1 is written to this bit, ECC encoding is enabled, but the NAND flash is not read or written.
When this bit is read, the return value 1 indicates that ECC encoding and decoding are complete and the value 0 indicates that ECC encoding and decoding are in progress.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_DMA_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_DMA_CTRL is a DMA control register.

Member.name: wr_cmd_disable
Member.description:
Whether the NANDC initiates a complete timing for reading/writing to the NAND flash.
0: The NANDC initiates a complete timing for reading/writing to the NAND flash.
1: The NANDC initiates a timing for reading/writing to data rather than a command.
That is, the NANDC initiates CS signals and read/write pulse signals for reading/writing data rather than the CLE and ALE signals.

Member.name: rw_nf_disable
Member.description:
Whether the DMA operation and the read/write operation are performed at the same time.
0: The DMA operation and the read/write operation on the NAND flash are performed at the same time.
1: Data is transferred between the buffer and the DDR, but the NAND flash is not read or written.

Member.name: dma_nf_cs
Member.description:
NAND flash CS select for operating the DMA.
00: CS 0
01: CS 1
Other values: reserved

Member.name: dma_addr_num
Member.description:
Number of addresses.
0: 5 addresses
1: 4 addresses

Member.name: burst16_en
Member.description:
Burst 16 enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: burst8_en
Member.description:
Burst 8 enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: burst4_en
Member.description:
Burst 4 enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: oob_area_en
Member.description:
OOB area write enable. This bit is valid only in 1-bit ECC mode.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: data_area_en
Member.description:
Data area write enable. This bit is valid only in 1-bit ECC mode.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: dma_wr_en
Member.description:
DMA read/write enable.
0: read
1: write

Member.name: dma_start
Member.description:
DMA operation enable.
When the value 1 is written to this bit, the DMA operations are enabled. The bit retains 1 until the DMA operations are complete. Writing 0 to this bit has no effect.
If the value 0 is returned after this bit is read, the DMA operations are complete.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_BADDR_D
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_BADDR_D is a base address register of the data transfer area in DMA mode.

Member.name: base_addr_d
Member.description: Base address of the DDR data area that stores the data to be read or written.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_BADDR_OOB
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_BADDR_OOB is a base address register of the OOB area in DMA mode.

Member.name: base_addr_oob
Member.description:
Base address of the OOB area that stores the data to be read.
This register is valid only when the NAND flash is written in DMA mode.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_DMA_LEN
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_DMA_LEN is a transfer length register in DMA mode.

Member.name: len_oob
Member.description: Length of the OOB area when the NAND flash is written in DMA mode. The long words must be 4-byte aligned. This field is valid only in ECC0 mode. In other modes, the OOB length is fixed.

Member.name: len_data
Member.description:
Length of the data to be read or written in DMA mode.
This field is valid only when rw_nf_disable is 1.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_OP_PARA
RegisterGroup.description: NF_OP_PARA is an operation parameter register.

Member.name: ext_len
Member.description:
Length of the extended data area to be corrected.
In 24-bit ECC mode, this field indicates the length of the extended data area in each ECC data block. In boot mode, when the page size is 4 KB, the default length is 8 bytes; when the page size is 8 KB, the default length is 4 bytes.
01: 4 bytes
11: 8 bytes
Other values: reserved

Member.name: oob_ecc_en
Member.description:
ECC correction enable in OOB area.
0: disabled
1: enabled
This field is valid only when data is read.

Member.name: data_ecc_en
Member.description:
ECC correction enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
This field is valid only when data is read.

Member.name: oob_edc_en
Member.description:
OOB area check enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
In programming mode, the function of generating the ECC code of the OOB area is enabled.
In data read mode, the check on the OOB area is enabled.

Member.name: data_edc_en
Member.description:
Check enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
In programming mode, ECC code is generated.
In data read mode, the check is enabled.

Member.name: oob_rw_en
Member.description:
Read/write redundancy enable for the data area of the NAND flash.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: data_rw_en
Member.description:
Read/write enable for the data area of the NAND flash.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_VERSION
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_VERSION is a version register.

Member.name: version_id
Member.description: Version number.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_BUF_BADDR
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_BUF_BADDR is a NANDC buffer base address register.

Member.name: buf_baddr_rd
Member.description:
Indicates the base address from which the buffer is read in DMA mode when rw_nf_disable is 1.
Indicates undefined when rw_nf_disable is 0.

Member.name: buf_baddr_wr
Member.description:
Indicates the base address from which the buffer is written in DMA mode when rw_nf_disable is 1.
Indicates undefined when rw_nf_disable is 0.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_RD_LOGIC_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_RD_LOGIC_ADDR is a logic address register for reading the NAND flash in DMAmode

Member.name: rd_logic_addr
Member.description:
Start address (excluding the ECC code) for reading data. For example, if you want to read data from the bad block flag, you can set the field value to 2048 for the 2 KB page size or 4096 for the 4 KB page size. After data is read in DMA mode, the field value is automatically accumulated based on the value of NFC_DMA_LEN[len_data].
The rd_logic_addr field is valid only when data is read in DMA mode and NFC_DMA_CTRL[rw_nf_disable] is 0.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_RD_LOGIC_LEN
RegisterGroup.description: NFC_RD_LOGIC_LEN is a logic length register for reading the NAND flash in DMA mode.

Member.name: rd_logic_len
Member.description:
Length (excluding the length of the ECC code) of the data read from the NAND flash in DMA mode. After data is read in DMA mode, the field value is cleared automatically.
The rd_logic_addr field is valid only when data is read in DMA mode and NFC_DMA_CTRL[rw_nf_disable] is 0.

RegisterGroup.name: NFC_FIFO_EMPTY

Member.name: addr_num

Number of addresses sent to the NAND flash by the NANDC during booting.
0: 4 address cycles
1: 5 address cycles.
The reset value depends on the nfc_addr_num pin.

Member.name: block_size
Member.description:
Bus width of the NAND flash during booting.
0: 64 pages
1: 128 pages
The reset value depends on the nfc_block_size pin.

000–111: n + 1 clock cycles (n = 0, 1, 2, …, or 7)

Indicates the deselect time of the CS. It is equal to the interval between two flash operations.
0000–1111: n + 2 clock cycles. (n = 0, 1, 2, …, or 15)

Member.description:
Physical address of the external PHY chip.
One MDIO can perform read/write operation on multiple external PHY chips. Each PHY chip has one corresponding address. When the MDIO connects to only one external PHY chip, this bit is equivalent to UD_MDIO_PHYADDR[phy0_addr] or UD_MDIO_PHYADDR[phy1_addr].

Member.name: frq_dv
Member.description:
Frequency division factor for the MDC (the MDIO interface clock) when the MDIO performs the read/write operation on external PHY chips.
Take the frequency 100 MHz of the main clock as an example to describe the matching relations between frq_dv and MDC frequency.
000: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 50 and the obtained frequency is 2 MHz.
001: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 100 and the obtained frequency is 1 MHz.
010: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 200 and the obtained frequency is 512 kHz.
011: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 400 and the obtained frequency is 256 kHz.
100: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 800 and the obtained frequency is 128 kHz.
101: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 1600 and the obtained frequency is 64 kHz.
110: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 3200 and the obtained frequency is 32 kHz.
111: The frequency of the working main clock is divided by 6400 and the obtained frequency is 16 kHz.

Member.name: phy_inaddr
Member.description: Internal register address of the external PHY chip. This address is presented by a 5-bit binary number.

RegisterGroup.name: MDIO_RO_DATA

RegisterGroup.name: UD_MDIO_ANEG_CTRL
RegisterGroup.description:
UD_MDIO_ANEG_CTRLPHY is a offset address configuration register for the PHY status.The register does not support soft reset.NOTE
The PHY speed status is indicated by bit[14] of the register with the address of 17, internal_addr_speedis set to 0x11 and speed_index is set to 0xE. In this case, the ETH module reads the bit value as thecurrent working speed mode of the PHY through the MDIO interface.

Member.name: internal_addr_speed
Member.description: Address of the register in the PHY chip to store the status information (speed). The default value is set according to Intel 9785.

Member.name: internal_addr_link
Member.description: Address of the register in the PHY chip to store the status information (link). The default value is set according to Intel 9785.

Member.name: internal_addr_duplex
Member.description: Address of the register in the PHY chip to store the status information (duplex). The default value is set according to Intel 9785.

Member.name: speed_index
Member.description: Offset address in the PHY status register that is used to store the speed information. The default value is set according to Intel 9785.

Member.name: link_index
Member.description: Offset address in the PHY status register that is used to store the link information. The default value is set according to Intel 9785.

Member.name: duplex_index
Member.description: Offset address in the PHY status register that is used to store the duplex information. The default value is set according to Intel 9785.

Member.name: in_loop_en
Member.description:
Port loopback to internal enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: Loopback to internal enable and loopback to external enable cannot be configured at the same time. When the network interface is in normal state, you need to perform soft reset on the module after loopback to internal enable is configured instead of loopback to external enable and vice versa.

Member.name: ex_loop_en
Member.description:
Port loopback to external enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: Loopback to internal enable and loopback to external enable cannot be configured at the same time. When the network interface is in normal state, you need to perform soft reset on the module after loopback to internal enable is configured instead of loopback to external enable and vice versa.

Member.name: pause_en
Member.description:
Port pause frame TX enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: rx_shframe_en
Member.description:
Port short frame RX enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
Note: If rx_shframe_en is set to 1, the minimum RX frame length allowed by the port is that set by rx_min_thr. If rx_shframe_en is set to 0, the minimum RX frame length allowed by the port is 64 bytes (including CRC) by default.

Member.name: rx_min_thr
Member.description:
Minimum RX frame length allowed by the port.
The value range is from 42 bytes to 63 bytes. The default value is 42 bytes.
Note: If rx_min_thr is set to a value smaller than 42, 42 is used instead of the value.

Member.name: len_max
Member.description:
Maximum RX frame length allowed by the port. The default value is 1518 bytes.
The value is in a range of 1518 bytes to 1535 bytes.
Note: If len_max is set to a value greater than 2000, 2000 is used instead of the value. If len_max is set to a value smaller than 256, 256 is used instead of the value.

RegisterGroup.name: GLB_IRQ_STAT
RegisterGroup.description: GLB_IRQ_STAT is an interrupt status register.The register does not support soft reset.

Member.name: int_mdio_finish
Member.description:
Interrupt status indicates whether the MDIO interface completes the operation required by the CPU.
0: Not completed.
1: Completed and an interrupt is generated.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether the MDIO completes the operation by querying MDIO_RWCTRL[finish].

Member.name: int_rxd_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status (multi-packet interrupt) for a frame (frames) on the port to be received by the CPU.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid. There are frames to be received by the CPU in the RX queue.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether there are frames to be received by querying GLB_IRQ_RAW[iraw_rxd_up].

Member.name: int_freeeq_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status indicates that the status of the port output queue is changed from nonempty to empty, that is, the status of the TX queue buffer is changed from nonempty to empty, that is, the status of the TX queue buffer is changed from nonempty to empty. In this case, the CPU can write a group of new frames to be transmitted.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether the current TX queue is empty by querying UD_GLB_ADDRQ_STAT[eq_cnt]. If the current TX queue is not empty, it indicates that the interrupt is invalid.

Member.name: int_stat_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status for port status changes, indicating that an interrupt is generated when the MDIO obtains the speed change, duplex mode change, and link status change of the PHY chip in auto-adaption mode.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid. The port status changes.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines which status changes according to the configuration of UD_MDIO_IRQENA.

Member.name: int_duplex_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status for port duplex mode changes.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid. The duplex mode changes.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether the duplex mode changes by querying UD_MAC_STAT_CHANGE[duplex_stat_ch].

Member.name: int_speed_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status for port speed mode changes.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid. The speed mode changes.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether the speed mode changes by querying UD_MAC_STAT_CHANGE[speed_stat_ch].

Member.name: int_link_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status for port link status changes.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid. The link status changes.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether the link status changes by querying UD_MAC_STAT_CHANGE[link_stat_ch].

Member.name: int_tx_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status for the completion of transmitting a frame from the CPU by the port.
0: Not completed.
1: Completed and an interrupt is generated.
After this interrupt is generated, software determines whether to release the buffer of the TX frames by querying the current TX queue address eq_out_index in UD_GLB_QSTAT.

Member.name: int_rx_up
Member.description:
Interrupt status for frames on the port to be received by the CPU.
0: The interrupt is invalid.
1: The interrupt is valid. There are frames to be received by the CPU in the RX queue.
After this interrupt program is started, software determines whether frames are received by querying the GLB_IRQ_RAW[iraw_rxd_up] signal.

1: yes

Member.name: mac6_up
Member.description:
Control for setting this filter to be used by the uplink port.

1: The uplink port uses this filter.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_IRQN_SET
RegisterGroup.description: UD_GLB_IRQN_SET is a multi-packet interrupt configuration register.The register does not support soft reset.

Member.name: int_frm_cnt
Member.description:
These bits are used to set the multi-packet interrupt function. That is, how many packets must be received before a multi-packet interrupt can be reported.
Note: The minimum value of int_frm_cnt can be set to 1. In this case, multi-packet interrupt is equivalent to single-packet interrupt.

Member.name: age_timer
Member.description:
After the multi-packet interrupt function is enabled, if the number of received packets cannot reach the specified number of packets required for reporting the multi-packet interrupt after a period, this period is defined as the aging time for generating the multi-packet interrupt.
Note: age_timer is counted in the unit of the main clock cycle divided by 256.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_QLEN_SET
RegisterGroup.description: UD_GLB_QLEN_SET is a queue length configuration register.The register does not support soft reset.

Member.name: iq_len
Member.description:
RX (packet RX) queue length configuration.
Note: iq_len cannot be set to 0. Otherwise, it is forcibly set to 1. The sum of the set values of iq_len and eq_len cannot be greater than 64. Otherwise, the value (non-zero) of iq_len is firstly assigned and the value of eq_len is calculated by the formula: 64 – iq_len.

Member.name: eq_len
Member.description:
TX (packet TX) queue length configuration.
Note: eq_len cannot be set to 0. Otherwise, it is forcibly set to 1.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_FC_LEVEL
RegisterGroup.description: UD_GLB_FC_LEVEL is a traffic control register.The register does not support soft reset.

Member.name: qlimit_ena
Member.description:
Traffic control enable for RX queue.
0: Disabled (do not transmit the traffic control message according to the status of RX queue).
1: Enabled (transmit the traffic control message according to the status of RX queue).

Member.name: qlimit_up
Member.description:
Upper limit of traffic control for RX queue. When the free space of the RX queue is less than the upper limit, if traffic control for RX queue is enabled, the traffic control message is transmitted to the peer end.
Note: If the upper limit qlimit_up is set to 0, the RX queue fails to enter the traffic control status.
The upper limit qlimit_up must be greater than the lower limit qlimit_down.

Member.name: qlimit_down
Member.description: Lower limit of traffic control for RX queue. When the free space of the RX queue is equal to or greater than the upper limit, if the RX queue is in traffic control state, the current traffic control is stopped.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_CAUSE
RegisterGroup.description: UD_GLB_CAUSE is a cause register for the CPU to which the packet is transmitted.The register does not support soft reset.

Member.name: mact_cause
Member.description:
Packet matching result types by querying the MAC table.
000: Forced forwarding.
001: Packet whose destination MAC address is the local MAC address.
010: Broadcast packet.
011: Packet matching the MAC table.
100: Multicast packet not matching the MAC table.
101: Unicast packet not matching the MAC table.
Others: Reserved.

Member.name: fd_in_len

Member.name: flowctrl_cnt

Register for the count of the forward buffer of the uplink or downlink port entering the traffic control status.
Note: If the value of flowctrl_cnt is too large in a unit of time, it indicates that UD_GLB_FC_LEVEL[blimit_up] or UD_GLB_FC_LEVEL[blimit_down] is set to a too small value, or the external network condition is worsened. In this case, the configured value may be reduced.

Member.name: cpuaddr_in_rdy
Member.description:
Indicates whether the CPU can configure the frame header address of the RX queue.
0: The CPU cannot configure the frame header address of the RX queue.
1: The CPU can configure the frame header address of the RX queue.
Note: The values of cpuaddr_in_rdy and eq_in_rdy are set to 0 during reset. The values, however, are set to 1 by the circuit immediately after reset. In other words, after reset, the iq address queue and eq descriptor queue are configurable.

Member.name: eq_in_rdy
Member.description:
Indicates whether the CPU can configure the frame descriptor (header address and length) of the TX queue.
0: The CPU cannot configure the frame descriptor (header address and length) of the TX queue.
1: The CPU can configure the frame descriptor (header address and length) of the TX queue.

Member.description: Header address count for available frames assigned by the CPU to the RX queue.

Member.name: iq_cnt
Member.description: Used length of the RX queue (0 to iq_len).

Member.name: eq_cnt
Member.description: Used length of the TX queue (0 to eq_len).

Member.name: flux_timer_inter
Member.description: Traffic limit time slot counter, which is used to count the main clock. The default count is 100,000. For a 100-MHz main clock, the time slot is 1 ms.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_EQ_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
UD_GLB_EQ_ADDR is a TX queue header address register.The register does not support soft reset.NOTE
If the header address of the TX frame is not word aligned, the logic reads data according to the wordaligned address. In this case, the previously read data is invalid and discarded. For example, if theconfigured header address of the TX frame is 0xF000_8102 (non-word-aligned address), the logicdirectly discards the byte data read from the 0xF000_8100 and 0xF000_8101 addresses. Then, the logicconsiders the data read from the 0xF000_8102 address as the first byte (valid data) of the TX frame andconsiders the data read from the 0xF000_8103 address as the second byte (valid data) of the TX frame.All subsequent data is valid (until the data of the specified frame length is read). If the configured headeraddress of the TX frame is other non-word-aligned address, the logic reads data in a similar way.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_IQ_ADDR
RegisterGroup.description:
UD_GLB_IQ_ADDR is an RX frame header address register.The register does not support soft reset.NOTE
If the address assigned by software is not word aligned, the logic writes data according to the wordaligned address. In this case, the previously written data is invalid. For example, if the configured headeraddress of a frame is 0xF000_8002 (non-word-aligned address), the logic writes 0x00 or other data toboth the 0xF000_8000 and 0xF000_8001 addresses. Then, the logic writes the first byte (valid data) ofthe RX frame to the 0xF000_8002 address, writes the second byte (valid data) of the RX frame to the0xF000_8003 address. Subsequent data is written to the buffer in sequence. If the configured headeraddress of the RX frame is other non-word-aligned address, the logic writes data in a similar way.

RegisterGroup.name: UD_GLB_RXFRM_SADDR

Member.name: imgheightinpixelsminus1
Member.description: Picture height. The value is in the unit of pixel, and the configured value is obtained by subtracting 1 from the actual height. For example, if the picture height is 352 pixels, this field must be set to 351 pixels.

Member.name: imgwidthinpixelsminus1
Member.description: Picture width. The value is in the unit of pixel, and the configured value is obtained by subtracting 1 from the actual width. For example, if the picture width is 288 pixels, this field must be set to 287 pixels.

Member.name: timeout_en
Member.description:
MDU timeout detection enable. If this field is enabled, the upper limits of the working cycle that is configured using MDU_TIMEOUT by the software can be automatically queried.

1: enabled

Member.name: md_mod

Motion detection mode.

1: frame reference algorithm

Member.name: bg_update_en
Member.description:

This field is valid only when md_mod is set to 0 (background algorithm).

Member.name: eg_find_en

1: enabled
If the background algorithm is selected, only the last joint detection based on the background is disabled.

Member.name: obj_out_en

OBJ region output enable. If this field is enabled, MDU_OBJ_ADDR must be configured.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: sad_out_en

1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: INT_EN
RegisterGroup.description: INT_EN is an interrupt enable register.

Member.name: list_int_en
Member.description:
Link table interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: node_int_en
Member.description:
Node interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

RegisterGroup.name: INT_RW
RegisterGroup.description: INT_RW is a raw interrupt register.

Member.name: list_int_rw
Member.description:
Link table raw interrupt. After reading an interrupt through INT_STATUS, the software writes INT_RW to clear the interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: node_int_rw
Member.description:
Node raw interrupt. After reading an interrupt through INT_STATUS, the software writes INT_RW to clear the interrupt.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: INT_STATUS
RegisterGroup.description: INT_STATUS is an interrupt status register.

Member.name: list_int_status
Member.description:
Link table interrupt status. The software determines whether a linked list interrupt is generated by reading this bit.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

Member.name: node_int_status
Member.description:
Node interrupt status. The software determines whether a node interrupt is generated by reading this bit.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DSD1VSYNC
RegisterGroup.description: DSD1VSYNC is the DSD1 vertical timing register. In interlaced output mode, this registerindicates the top vertical sync timing; in progressive output mode, this register indicates theframe vertical sync timing. The setting of this register takes effect immediately afterconfiguration. That is, the timing of the VSYNC pin is affected immediately.CAUTIONYou must configure this register before configuring DSDCTRL[intf_en]. Otherwise, theconfiguration does not take effect.

Member.description:
In interlaced output mode: TVFB
In progressive output mode: VFB
Unit: line

Member.name: vbb
Member.description:
In interlaced output mode: TVBB
In progressive output mode: VBB + VPW
Unit: line

Member.name: vact
Member.description:
In interlaced output mode: height of an active picture in the top field
In progressive output format: height of an active picture in a frame. The register value is the actual value minus 1.
Unit: line

Member.name: vtmgthd1
Member.description: Vertical timing threshold 1. When the vertical timing counter reaches this threshold, the VOINTSTA[dsdvtthd_int1] interrupt is triggered.

RegisterGroup.name: DATE_COEFF8

Member.name: tt_staddr
Member.description: Start address of the teletext data.

RegisterGroup.name: DATE_COEFF9
RegisterGroup.description: DATE_COEFF9 is a DATE teletext configuration register.

Member.name: tt_edaddr
Member.description: End address of the teletext data.

RegisterGroup.name: DATE_COEFF10
RegisterGroup.description: DATE_COEFF10 is a DATE teletext configuration register.CAUTIONThe teletext function is supported in both 625-line mode and 525-line mode. The tt_mode bitis set to 01 in 625-line mode or 10 in 525-line mode.

Member.name: tt_ready
Member.description:
When software sets related parameters through the bus, this bit is set to 1 and the teletext module starts to work.
When the teletext module completes data transfer, this bit is set to 0. The bit status can be queried through software for the next configuration.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: nabts_100ire
Member.description:
NABTS-NTSC data height.
0: 70 IRE
1: 100 IRE

Member.name: full_page
Member.description:
Teletext data transmission mode.
0: normal mode. The teletext data is transmitted from the blanking line.
1: full page mode. The teletext data can also be transmitted from the active video region.

Member.name: tt_highest
Member.description:
Teletext priority control.
0: The teletext data has the highest priority.
1: The teletext data has the lowest priority.

Member.name: tt_mode
Member.description:
Teletext mode.
This field is set to 01 in 625-line mode, indicating WST-PAL.
This field is set to 10 in 525-line mode, indicating NABTS-NTSC.

Member.name: tt_pktoff
Member.description: Offset address of the teletext packet.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:

Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: tt_mask
Member.description:
Teletext interrupt mask.
0: enabled
1: masked

RegisterGroup.name: DATE_ISRSTATE
RegisterGroup.description: DATE_ISRSTATE is the DATE interrupt status register.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: tt_status
Member.description:
Teletext interrupt flag.
After the DATE module reads all the teletext data, the bit is set to 1. Writing 1 to this bit clears this bit.

RegisterGroup.name: DATE_ISR
RegisterGroup.description: DATE_ISR is the DATE interrupt register.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: tt_int
Member.description:
Teletext interrupt. It is the interrupt status after tt_status is masked by tt_mask.
0: No interrupt is generated.
1: An interrupt is generated.

RegisterGroup.name: DATE_VERSION
RegisterGroup.description: DATE_VERSION is the DATE version register.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

RegisterGroup.name: DATE1_COEFF0
RegisterGroup.description: DATE1_COEFF0 is the DATE1 norm parameter configuration register.

Member.name: clpf_sel
Member.description:
Bandwidth select of the chrominance low-pass filter.
00: 1.1 MHz (NTSC)
01: 1.3 MHz (PAL)
10: 1.6 MHz (for test)
11: reserved

Member.name: dis_ire
Member.description:
For the (M) NTSC and (M, N) PAL norms, the black level is 7.5 IRE higher than the blanking level; for other norms, the black level is equal to the blanking level.
This bit controls whether the black level is 7.5 IRE higher than the blanking level.
0: The black level is 7.5 IRE higher than the blanking level.
1: The black level is equal to the blanking level.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: scanline
Member.description:
Number of scanned lines in each frame based on norms. For the (M) NTSC, NTSC-J, and (M) PAL norm, each line contains 525 lines; for the (B, D, J, H, I) PAL, (N) PAL, and (Nc) PAL norms, each frame contains 625 lines.
0: 525 lines in a frame
1: 625 lines in a frame

Member.name: rgb_en
Member.description:
When intf_sel is set to 100, this bit determines whether the component signal is RGB or YPbPr.
0: YPbPr
1: RGB

Member.name: vbi_lpf_en
Member.description:
VBI data low-pass filtering enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: fm_sel
Member.description:
FMSECAM frequency modulation select.
0: sin used for SECAM frequency modulation
1: cos used for SECAM frequency modulation

Member.name: style_sel
Member.description:
CVBS/S-Video output signal norm when this bit works with the scanline bit.
When the scanline bit is 0 (525 scanned lines in a frame), the definition of the style_sel bit is as follows:
0x1: (M) NTSC
0x2: NTSC-J
0x4: (M) PAL
Other values: reserved
When the scanline bit is 1 (625 scanned lines in a frame), the definition of the style_sel bit is as follows:
0x1: (B, D, G, H, I) PAL
0x2: (N) PAL
0x4: (Nc) PAL
0x8: SECAM
Other values: reserved

Member.name: sync_mode_sel
Member.description:
bit[17]: specifies whether there are sync signals in three channels during component output. This bit takes effect only when the sync_mode_scart bit is set to 0.
bit[17] is valid only when the intf_sel is set to 100 (component output enabled). The definition of bit[17] is as follows:
0: Only one channel contains sync signals using component output.
1: Three channels contain sync signals during component output.
When bit[17] is set to 0, the sync channel must be the Y channel for YPbPr output and G channel for RGB output.
bit[16]: specifies whether there are blanking radixes during RGB output. bit[16] is valid only when the intf_sel is set to 100 and the rgb_en bit is set to 1. The definition of bit[16] is as follows:
0: There are no blanking radixes during RGB output.
1: There are blanking radixes during RGB output.

Member.name: sync_mode_scart
Member.description:
Overlay sync control of the components of three channels.
0: Component sync output is configured based on sync_mode_sel[1].
1: The components of the three channels are not overlaid and synchronized. In this case, sync_mode_sel bit[1] must be set to 0.

Member.name: length_sel
Member.description:
Active width of each video line (in pixel).
0: output according to the active line width in BT.601 mode
1: output according to the active line width in BT.470 mode.
When this bit is set to 0, the active width of the line is 720 pixels. When this bit is set to 1, the active width of the line is 704 pixels for the 625-line norm or 712 pixels for the 525-line norm. Currently, the BT.601 mode and BT.470 mode cannot be changed dynamically. You can change the mode only after reset. The BT.601 mode is recommended and this mode is the default value after power-on reset.

Member.name: agc_amp_sel
Member.description:
AGC pulse select.
0: The AGC pulse is generated based on the on-chip default value (recommended).
1: The AGC pulse is generated based on DATE_COEFF1[amp_outside].

Member.name: luma_dl
Member.description:
Forward or backward offset of the chrominance signal relative to the luminance signal, in the unit of half a pixel width.
bit[12]: offset direction of the chrominance signal relative to the luminance signal.
0: backward offset
1: forward offset
bit[11:9]: absolute offset of the chrominance signal relative to the luminance signal. The value is in binary format and ranges from 0 to 7.
000: The chrominance signal is aligned with the luminance signal. No adjustment is required.
001–111: The chrominance signal offsets from the luminance signal forward or backward by one to seven units.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: oversam_en
Member.description:
Level-1 oversampling enable. Both the luminance oversampling and chrominance oversampling are controlled.
bit[7]: luminance oversampling enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled
bit[6]: chrominance oversampling enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: lunt_en
Member.description:
Luminance notch enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: oversam2_en
Member.description:
Level-2 oversampling enable. Both the luminance channel and chrominance channel are controlled.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: chlp_en
Member.description:
Chrominance low-pass filtering enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: sylp_en
Member.description:
Sync low-pass filtering enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: chgain_en
Member.description:
Chrominance gain enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: tt_seq
Member.description:
Sequence of transmitting the bits of the teletext data.
0: from upper bits to lower bits
1: from lower bits to upper bits

RegisterGroup.name: DATE1_COEFF10
RegisterGroup.description: DATE1_COEFF10 is a DATE1 teletext configuration register.CAUTIONThe teletext function is supported in both 625-line mode and 525-line mode. The tt_mode bitis set to 01 in 625-line mode or 10 in 525-line mode.

Member.name: tt_ready
Member.description:
When software sets related parameters through the bus, this bit is set to 1 and the teletext module starts to work.
When the teletext module completes data transfer, this bit is set to 0. The bit status can be queried through software for the next configuration.

Member.name: reserved
Member.description:
Reserved.
Writing to this field has no effect and reading this field returns 0.

Member.name: nabts_100ire
Member.description:
NABTS-NTSC data height.
0: 70 IRE
1: 100 IRE

Member.name: full_page
Member.description:
Teletext data transmission mode.
0: normal mode. The teletext data is transmitted from the blanking line.
1: full page mode. The teletext data can also be transmitted from the active video region.

Member.name: tt_highest
Member.description:
Teletext priority control.
0: The teletext data has the highest priority.
1: The teletext data has the lowest priority.

Member.name: tt_mode
Member.description:
Teletext mode.
This field is set to 01 in 625-line mode, indicating WST-PAL.
This field is set to 10 in 525-line mode, indicating NABTS-NTSC.

Member.name: tt_pktoff
Member.description: Offset address of the teletext packet.

RegisterGroup.name: PT_GEN_DATA_COEF
RegisterGroup.description: PT_GEN_DATA_COEF is a data generation module coefficient register.

Member.name: inc_frame
Member.description: Pixel incremental value between frames. The incremental value is accumulated in the upper eight bits of data.

Member.name: step_frame
Member.description: Pixel value increment interval between frames. The configured value is the actual value minus 1. The value 0 indicates that the pixel value is incremented in each frame.

Member.name: inc_space
Member.description: Data pixel incremental value. The incremental value is accumulated in the upper 10 bits of data.

Member.name: step_space

RegisterGroup.name: CH_HFIR_C_SPH
RegisterGroup.description: CH_HFIR_C_SPH is a chrominance horizontal scaling parameter configuration register.

Member.name: enable
Member.description:
Chrominance horizontal scaling enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: ratio
Member.description: Chrominance horizontal scaling ratio. It is calculated by dividing the input width by the output width. If horizontal pre-processing is enabled, the input width after pre-processing is used. The ratio is in the format of (u, 4). That is, the ratio consists of a 1-bit unsigned bit and a 4-bit integral part.

RegisterGroup.name: CH_HFIR_C_OFFSET
RegisterGroup.description: CH_HFIR_C_OFFSET is a chrominance scaling horizontal offset register.

Member.name: offset
Member.description: Chrominance horizontal start position offset. It is in the format of (s, 5). That is, the offset consists of a 1-bit signed part and a 4-bit integral part. The offset is expressed as the complementary code and ranges from –4 to +15.

Member.description:
Dither mode select.
000: 12-bit inputs, 10-bit outputs, no dithering, and direct bit truncation
001: 12-bit inputs, 10-bit outputs, and time-domain dithering
010: 12-bit inputs, 10-bit outputs, and spatial-domain dithering
011: 12-bit inputs, 8-bit outputs, and time-domain and spatial-domain dithering
100: 12-bit inputs, 10-bit outputs, and round off
101: 12-bit inputs, 8-bit outputs, and round off
111: no operation

RegisterGroup.name: SIO_VERSION
RegisterGroup.description: SIO_VERSION is an SIO version register. It is used to record the SIO version number andperform the SIO self-test.

Member.name: sio_loop
Member.description:
SIO loop or normal mode select.
0: normal mode
1: Data transmit and receive loop mode. It is used for the self-test of the SIO. In the mode, the SIO receive serial data line is directly connected to the SIO transmit serial data line at the external interface of the SIO.

Member.name: version
Member.description: Version number of the SIO.

RegisterGroup.name: SIO_MODE
RegisterGroup.description:
SIO_MODE is an SIO mode register. It is used to select the basic operating mode of the SIOas follows:
  • In master mode, the clock reset generator (CRG) transmits clocks and sync signals to theCODEC and SIO.
  • In slave mode, the external CODEC transmits clocks and sync signals to the SIO.For details about the master/slave mode selection of the I2S, see "错误！未找到引用源。" insection 错误！未找到引用源。"Operating Mode."

Member.name: chn_num
Member.description:
Number of channels during multi-channel data receive.
00: 2 channels
01: 4 channels
10: 8 channels
11: 16 channels

Member.name: ext_rec_en
Member.description:
In standard data receive mode, the I2S interface receives both the left-channel and right-channel data.
For the I2S interface in multi-channel data receive mode, the number of channels is configurable. Additionally, the bit width of the channels must be 8 bits or 16 bits.
0: standard data receive mode of the I2S interface
1: extended multi-channel data receive mode of the I2S interface

Member.name: reserved
Member.description: Reserved. This bit must be set to 0.

RegisterGroup.name: SIO_INTSTATUS
RegisterGroup.description: SIO_INTSTATUS is an SIO interrupt status register.Take the receive interrupt as an example. When the data depth of the RX FIFO is above thethreshold, the high level is always latched to the interrupt status register and the interrupts aregenerated continuously. That is, even if the CPU clears the interrupt, the interrupt statusregister is set to 1 in the next clock cycle. Therefore, the following processing mode of theCPU is recommended:Write 1 to SIO_CT_CLR[intr_en] to disable the global interrupt enable bit.Read the interrupt status register SIO_INTSTATUS.Perform related operations according to the interrupt source.Write 1 to the related bit of SIO_INTCLR to clear the interrupt.Write 1 to SIO_CT_SET[intr_en] to enable the global interrupt enable bit.----EndThe transmit interrupt and receive interrupt are generated in the same way. Therefore, it isrecommended that the transmit interrupt is processed in the similar way.This register is a raw interrupt status register. If the related interrupt bit is masked and theinterrupt condition is met, the related interrupt status bit is set to 1 and no interrupt istriggered.

The bits beyond thevalid data width are automatically set to 0 by the SIO module.

RegisterGroup.name: SIO_CT_SET
RegisterGroup.description: To operate the SIO control register by bits, the SIO_CT_SET register with the address 0x05Cis provided. When 1 is written to the related bit of the register, the bit is set to 1. Writing 0 hasno effect. This is a read/write register.

Member.name: rst_n
Member.description:
I2S channel reset, active low.
This bit is used to reset the transmit and receive modules (including the FIFOs) in I2S mode. Therefore, the RX FIFO and TX FIFO status registers are changed to 0. This bit does not reset the CPU interface register module.

Member.name: intr_en
Member.description:
Global interrupt enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: rx_enable
Member.description:
RX channel enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: tx_enable
Member.description:
TX channel enable.
0: disabled
1: enabled

Member.name: rx_fifo_disable
Member.description:
RX FIFO disable.
0: enabled
1: disabled

Member.name: tx_fifo_disable
Member.description:
TX FIFO disable.
0: enabled
1: disabled

Member.name: rx_data_merge_en
Member.description:
Data receive merging enable. This bit is valid only when the data width is 16 bits in I2S mode.
0: disabled
1: enabled
If this bit is 1, the left-channel and right-channel data is merged into a 32-bit data and then is stored in the FIFO. The left-channel 16 bits occupy the 16 MSBs, and the right-channel 16 bits occupy the 16 LSBs. Therefore, the usage and buffer capacity of the FIFO is improved.
The CPU reads data from the RX_FIFO in the following order. That is, reads the 32-bit data (formed by merging the16-bit left-channel data and 16-bit right-channel data) from the left-channel FIFO, and then reads the 32-bit data from the right-channel FIFO. The CPU reads data in this manner repeatedly.

Member.name: tx_data_merge_en
Member.description:
Data transmit merging enable. It is valid only when the data bit width is 16 bits in I2S mode.
0: disabled
1: enabled
If this bit is 1, the left-channel and right-channel data is merged into a 32-bit data and then is stored in the FIFO. The left-channel 16 bits occupy the 16 MSBs, and the right-channel 16 bits occupy the 16 LSBs. Therefore, the usage and buffer capacity of the FIFO is improved.
The CPU writes data into the TX_FIFO in the following order. That is, writes the 32-bit data (formed by merging the16-bit left-channel data and 16-bit right-channel data) to the left-channel FIFO, and then writes the 32-bit data to the right-channel FIFO. The CPU writes data in this manner repeatedly.

Member.name: rx_fifo_threshold
Member.description:
RX_FIFO threshold.
When rx_right_depth ≥ (rx_fifo_threshold + 1), the receive interrupt and DMA request are reported.

Member.name: tx_fifo_threshold
Member.description:
TX_FIFO threshold.
When the tx_right_depth < (tx_fifo_threshold + 1), the transmit interrupt and DMA request are reported.

RegisterGroup.name: SIO_CT_SET
RegisterGroup.description: To facilitate the bit operation on the SIO control register, the SIO_CT_CLR register with theaddress of 0x06 is provided. When 1 is written to the related bit of the register, the bit is set to1. Writing 0 has no effect. This is a write-only register.

Member.name: rst_n
Member.description:
I2S channel reset, active low.
This bit is used to reset the transmit and receive modules (including the FIFOs) in I2S mode. Therefore, the RX_FIFO and TX_FIFO status registers are changed to 0. This bit does not reset the CPU interface register module.

Member.description:
Global interrupt enable.

1: enabled

Member.description:
RX channel enable.

1: enabled

Member.name: tx_enable

Member.name: tx_fifo_disable
